prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Content: Milk forms a skin on top when heated because of a chemical reaction that affects how protein and fat molecules interact with each other. When milk is heated rapidly, some of the water in it evaporates from the surface. This exposes proteins and fat molecules, which bind and dry out as warming continues. Skin most commonly forms when milk is heated over a stove top, as stoves are generally capable of reaching very high temperatures quite quickly, though it can happen in the microwave as well. The film is not harmful, but is distasteful to many and can be prevented with constant stirring and a close eye on temperature.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Content: It is often surprising to see a film or skin on nonfat or “skim” milk, since it would seem that, without fat, the proteins would have nothing to bind to. In truth, it is rare to encounter milk that is truly fat free. Most of the skim milk that is sold commercially has very low fat content, but is rarely ever truly fat-free. Even trace amounts of fat on the surface can contribute to skin formation.


A similar phenomenon happens with soy milk, which is generally marketed as fat free. Natural fats still occur in trace amounts, and can be drawn to the surface when exposed to very high temperatures. Soy film can be discarded, but is also considered a delicacy in many Asian cultures. When removed and dried, it is referred to as yuba, or soybean curd, which is used in a variety of recipes.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Milk skin (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: Milk skin or lactoderm refers to a sticky film of protein that forms on top of dairy milk and foods containing dairy milk (such as hot chocolate and some soups). Milk film can be produced both through conventional boiling and by microwaving the liquid, and as such can often be observed when heating milk for use in drinks such as drinking chocolate. It is caused by the denaturation of proteins such as beta-lactoglobulin (whey protein). The thickness of the skin varies dependent on a number of factors, including the temperature of the milk, the shape of the container, and the amount of milk in the container.


When milk is boiled, soluble milk proteins are denatured and then coagulate with milk's fat and form a sticky film across the top of the liquid, which then dries by evaporation. The layer does not need to be discarded and can be consumed, as protein's nutritional value is unaffected by the denaturation process. Milk film is often considered to be desirable and is used in several recipes for various foods.
---

简言之，是否“结皮”取决于液体中是否存在会在加热和蒸发过程中变性并互相连接的大分子，以及蒸发／受热条件是否足以使其在表面固化。
claims_retained: 当液体被加热或长时间暴露空气时，表面的水分蒸发；若液体中含有蛋白质、脂肪等胶体粒子，这些粒子便被暴露并开始聚集[1]。
随后温度继续升高使蛋白质变性，与脂肪凝结并在蒸发作用下干燥，形成一层黏韧的膜，即所谓的“皮”[3]。
因此，即便标称无脂肪，仍含微量脂肪与蛋白的大豆饮料也会出现类似豆皮[2]。
皮膜的厚度还受液体温度、容器形状及液体量等因素影响[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Content: Milk forms a skin on top when heated because of a chemical reaction that affects how protein and fat molecules interact with each other. When milk is heated rapidly, some of the water in it evaporates from the surface. This exposes proteins and fat molecules, which bind and dry out as warming continues. Skin most commonly forms when milk is heated over a stove top, as stoves are generally capable of reaching very high temperatures quite quickly, though it can happen in the microwave as well. The film is not harmful, but is distasteful to many and can be prevented with constant stirring and a close eye on temperature.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Content: It is often surprising to see a film or skin on nonfat or “skim” milk, since it would seem that, without fat, the proteins would have nothing to bind to. In truth, it is rare to encounter milk that is truly fat free. Most of the skim milk that is sold commercially has very low fat content, but is rarely ever truly fat-free. Even trace amounts of fat on the surface can contribute to skin formation.


A similar phenomenon happens with soy milk, which is generally marketed as fat free. Natural fats still occur in trace amounts, and can be drawn to the surface when exposed to very high temperatures. Soy film can be discarded, but is also considered a delicacy in many Asian cultures. When removed and dried, it is referred to as yuba, or soybean curd, which is used in a variety of recipes.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Milk skin (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: Milk skin or lactoderm refers to a sticky film of protein that forms on top of dairy milk and foods containing dairy milk (such as hot chocolate and some soups). Milk film can be produced both through conventional boiling and by microwaving the liquid, and as such can often be observed when heating milk for use in drinks such as drinking chocolate. It is caused by the denaturation of proteins such as beta-lactoglobulin (whey protein). The thickness of the skin varies dependent on a number of factors, including the temperature of the milk, the shape of the container, and the amount of milk in the container.


When milk is boiled, soluble milk proteins are denatured and then coagulate with milk's fat and form a sticky film across the top of the liquid, which then dries by evaporation. The layer does not need to be discarded and can be consumed, as protein's nutritional value is unaffected by the denaturation process. Milk film is often considered to be desirable and is used in several recipes for various foods.
---

claim: 梦游发生在最深的非快速动眼睡眠阶段，睡眠者的运动控制区被激活而意识仍沉睡，因此他们虽能睁眼起身、走动并执行日常动作，却并未进行真正有意识的决策；看似“决定”实际上是大脑在半醒状态下的自动程序。
question_src: 人们如何安全地梦游？为什么人们在梦游时做出决定？
all_claims: 梦游发生在最深的非快速动眼睡眠阶段，睡眠者的运动控制区被激活而意识仍沉睡，因此他们虽能睁眼起身、走动并执行日常动作，却并未进行真正有意识的决策；看似“决定”实际上是大脑在半醒状态下的自动程序[2]。
要让梦游过程尽量安全，关键是防止受伤：首先保持环境无锋利或危险物，并阻止其接触车辆等高风险场所，因为让梦游者在危险区域徘徊比唤醒本身更具威胁[3]；其次轻声讲话或轻轻转身引导，将他们安全送回卧室，如有抵抗则陪伴在侧以避险[3]；若确需唤醒，应通过制造较大的声响而非剧烈摇晃或用力触碰，以减少惊吓和攻击性反应[3]。
此外，充足睡眠、避免睡眠剥夺及夜间频繁醒来，可降低梦游发生的概率[1]。
claims_retained: 梦游发生在最深的非快速动眼睡眠阶段，睡眠者的运动控制区被激活而意识仍沉睡，因此他们虽能睁眼起身、走动并执行日常动作，却并未进行真正有意识的决策；看似“决定”实际上是大脑在半醒状态下的自动程序[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Sleepwalking - Causes, Symptoms, & Treatments - Sleep Foundation (www.sleepfoundation.org)
Content: Sleepwalking, formally known as somnambulism, is a behavior disorder that originates during deep sleep and results in walking or performing other complex behaviors while still mostly asleep. It is more common in children than adults and is more likely to occur if a person has a family history of the condition, is sleep deprived, or is prone to repeated nighttime awakenings.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Do People Sleepwalk? Causes, Symptoms, Dangers, More (www.healthline.com)
Content: Sleepwalking is a sleeping disturbance that occurs in the deepest part of your nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. It most often occurs within 1 to 2 hours of falling asleep.


During an episode of sleepwalking, you may sit up, walk around, and even perform ordinary activities — all while sleeping. Your eyes are open, but you’re actually still in a deep state of sleep.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 5 Steps for Stopping a Sleepwalker (www.webmd.com)
Content: Waking someone who is sleepwalking can be dangerous, but allowing a sleepwalker to roam about a room filled with sharp objects or to jump into the driver's seat of a vehicle is what's really hazardous.


The lesson: Stop sleepwalkers and get them back to bed. How? Gently turn them around and make sure they return to the bedroom safely. If they resist, stay with them and help them avoid perilous objects and situations. If you must awaken them, do so with loud noises rather than by shaking or touching them roughly.
---

question_src: 2Pac自去世以来就有5个好战。发生了什么事，谁拥有权利？似乎与一百万不同的艺术家在一起
all_claims: 图帕克1996年遇害后，他留下的海量未发表录音被母亲阿芬尼·沙库尔创立的 Amaru Entertainment 与原东家 Death Row Records 共同控制，因此得以持续发行作品；截至目前，双方已将遗存素材整理成六张死后录音室专辑并售出数百万张[2]。
版权结构的核心是：Amaru 代表沙库尔遗产掌握词曲与大部分母带，Death Row（后来多次易主）保有部分发行权，再按专辑项目分别授权给不同厂牌或制作人。
为保持商业热度，专辑常由当时炙手可热的制作人“拼盘”完成：例如第五张专辑有 17 首歌，其中 13 首的配乐由阿姆与长期搭档 Luis Resto 重新制作[1]；《Pac Music》双 CD 又邀请 Johnny “J”、QDIII、L.T. Hutton 等老伙伴补完音轨[3]。
正因为遗产公司采用开放授权、每张专辑都重新“编配”，才会出现看似“和上百万艺术家合作”的局面；实质上，词曲主体仍出自 2Pac 生前录音，而制作层面的多方参与只是为了让老素材符合当时市场声音，同时最大化版权收益。

Title: What Could Be Causing Your Chronic Nausea? (www.verywellhealth.com)
Content: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common condition that occurs when stomach contents come back up into the esophagus. This can cause symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and nausea.


Symptoms might be worse after eating or at night after lying down. The nausea may linger, especially if stomach acid backs up into the throat.

question_src: 为什么有些人会深深而生动地梦想，而另一些人很少记住自己的梦想？

足够的快速动眼期（REM）是储存梦记忆的前提，长期失眠或睡眠被打断会减少REM，使回忆梦境更困难 [2]。
人格也起作用——喜欢白日梦、具创造性与自省特质的人更常记住梦，而务实、外向者则相反 [2]。
此外，对外界刺激更敏感者夜间易短暂觉醒，这类短醒可“标记”并巩固梦记忆，解释了他们平均每周能在五个清晨回忆梦境的现象 [3]；而压力或创伤则可能令梦更生动，从而增加次日的记忆概率 [2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Content: Basically, this theory suggests that dreams occur when our brain is processing information, eliminating the unnecessary stuff and moving important short-term memories into our long-term memory. So people who recall dreams may have a difference in their ability to memorize things in general.


Beyond that, a person’s brain may actually block out a dream so we don’t remember it the following day. “The dream activity can be so real and intense that our brains actually hide, or mask away the dream, so [it doesn’t] get lost between our waking experience, and our dream lives. Thus it is normal to forget dreams, most of the time.” Dimitriu says.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Content: A study published in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology and reported by International Business Times suggested that those people who reported high dream recall had more activity in the temporoparietal junction than those who didn’t recall their dreams often.


Lambert tells Healthline that if someone consistently doesn’t get enough sleep, the amount of REM sleep they experience will drop, making it harder for them to remember their dreams the following day.


Even personality traits can be an indicator of whether someone will be able to remember their dreams.


Lambert continues: “Researchers also looked at the most common personality traits that are presented in people who can recall their dreams. Overall, such people are prone to daydreaming, creative thinking, and introspection. At the same time, those who are more practical and focused on what is outside themselves tend to have difficulty remembering their dreams.”


This may mean that some people are naturally more likely to recall their dreams than others, despite their quality of sleep.


Other factors, like stress or experiencing a trauma, can also cause people to have vivid dreams or nightmares that they’re more likely to recall the next day. For example, a person who’s coping with grief after losing a loved one may dream about the death in elaborate detail. Remembering the dream the next day may affect mood and cause even more stress or anxiety.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Do Frequent Dreams and the Ability to Recall Them Indicate Depression? - Guardian Liberty Voice (guardianlv.com)
Content: People who have the ability to recall their dreams five mornings per week, on average, have more spontaneous activity occurring in certain parts of their brains than others. The parts of the brain that host these increased levels of activity are called the temporo-parietal junction, which is an information-processing hub, and the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for the expression of personality as well as the planning of complex cognitive behaviors. And, interestingly, this escalation in liveliness is higher during both wakefulness and sleep, so says a study of 41 people recently published online February 19 in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology. The activity in the brains of the people in this study were measured by Positron Emission Tomography while they were awake and sleeping. What do these findings tell us?


In combination with previous research from one of the study’s authors, Perrine Ruby, the findings tell us why some people remember their dreams and some do not. Ruby co-authored related research that was published last year in the journal Cerebral Cortex, which showed that people who have the ability to regularly recall their dreams are also more reactive to sounds when they are both asleep and awake. Ruby made some comments in a recent statement that synthesized the findings for both of these studies. Ruby stated that the brain needs to awaken from sleep in order to memorize new information. This, said Ruby, may explain the reason that those who react more to environmental stimuli can remember their dreams better; they simply are awakened more often and can therefore better encode into memory their dreams than others who are less reactive to sounds. In addition, the researchers said that people who often recall their dreams may also have more dreams than “low-recall” dreamers.
---

Other factors, like stress or experiencing a trauma, can also cause people to have vivid dreams or nightmares that they’re more likely to recall the next day. For example, a person who’s coping with grief after losing a loved one may dream about the death in elaborate detail. Remembering the dream the next day may affect mood and cause even more stress or anxiety.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Do Frequent Dreams and the Ability to Recall Them Indicate Depression? - Guardian Liberty Voice (guardianlv.com)
Content: People who have the ability to recall their dreams five mornings per week, on average, have more spontaneous activity occurring in certain parts of their brains than others. The parts of the brain that host these increased levels of activity are called the temporo-parietal junction, which is an information-processing hub, and the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for the expression of personality as well as the planning of complex cognitive behaviors. And, interestingly, this escalation in liveliness is higher during both wakefulness and sleep, so says a study of 41 people recently published online February 19 in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology. The activity in the brains of the people in this study were measured by Positron Emission Tomography while they were awake and sleeping. What do these findings tell us?


In combination with previous research from one of the study’s authors, Perrine Ruby, the findings tell us why some people remember their dreams and some do not. Ruby co-authored related research that was published last year in the journal Cerebral Cortex, which showed that people who have the ability to regularly recall their dreams are also more reactive to sounds when they are both asleep and awake. Ruby made some comments in a recent statement that synthesized the findings for both of these studies. Ruby stated that the brain needs to awaken from sleep in order to memorize new information. This, said Ruby, may explain the reason that those who react more to environmental stimuli can remember their dreams better; they simply are awakened more often and can therefore better encode into memory their dreams than others who are less reactive to sounds. In addition, the researchers said that people who often recall their dreams may also have more dreams than “low-recall” dreamers.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 1.4 UEFI... The Microsoft Kill Switch (www.learnlinuxandlibreoffice.org)
Content: As if the insanity of handing the keys to our computers over to Microsoft was not bad enough, in June 2016, two computer security researchers discovered that Microsoft was doing some rather reckless things with these Golden Keys. Microsoft developers wanted to make changes to certain devices without going through the hassle of getting authorized keys to Secure Boot. So they developed a secret “super policy” for bypassing Secure Boot completely. Had this Golden Key “super policy” been discovered by hackers it would have given them unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world. The only good news to this story is that this backdoor nuclear weapon was discovered by “Good Guy” researchers before it was discovered by Bad Guy hackers. https://www.infoworld.com/article/3106079/security/secure-boot-proves-insecurity-of-backdoors.html


After the researchers notified Microsoft of the issue, the company released a security patch MS16-094 in July 2016. This “golden key” super policy is now blocked from loading on computers with the July patch installed. However, the July patch is not a complete fix -- it's at most a small roadblock. The issue remains only partially addressed, and what's worse, it is believed that it is impossible for Microsoft to fully revoke the leaked Golden Key Super policy.


[Image: 1.4.09]


Because of the implications of this Golden Key Backdoor being released to the wild, the two researchers wrote a letter to the FBI explaining why the entire concept of having super keys to all computers was a bad idea:


“Microsoft implemented a 'secure golden key' system. And the golden keys got released by Microsoft's own stupidity. Now, what happens if you tell everyone to make a 'secure golden key' system? This is a perfect real-world example about why your idea of backdooring cryptosystems with a 'golden key' is very bad!”


The first lesson we should learn from the 2016 Golden Key incident is that keys and secrets will eventually get leaked or stolen. The second lesson is that a fix is not always possible.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Microsoft Leaks Secure Boot Key, Raises Security Concerns (www.informationweek.com)
Content: Microsoft is causing major cyber-security concerns with the accidental leak of a "golden key" intended to protect devices equipped with Secure Boot.


The Secure Boot feature is intended to protect Windows devices by making sure they only use software trusted by the PC maker or user. It's part of Microsoft's Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and ensures each component loaded during the boot process is validated.


The all-access keys were discovered by MY123 and Slipstream in March 2016. A recent blog post (animated site with tinny, arcade-style music) by researchers at MY123 and Slipstream dives into the details of Microsoft's security problems and the errors it made in addressing them.


[Google: QuadRooter threat is blocked on most Android devices.]


Note that the golden key isn't an actual key, but a means of changing the tasks launched by UEFI during the boot process, as explained in a report by Ars Technica. The policy has been made available online. It will enable anyone to disable the Secure Boot feature.


Secure Boot can be disabled on several types of desktop PCs, but is hard-coded into most devices running Windows. It seems the golden key is intended to turn off OS checks so programmers can test new projects. However, it can also leave Windows devices vulnerable.


The keys leaked by Microsoft will allow users with admin rights to install any operating system -- like Linux or Android -- on their Windows PCs, smartphones, or tablets.
---

微软虽在 2016 年 7 月发布 MS16-094 补丁，但只能增加障碍，无法吊销已泄漏的签名，后门事实上无法彻底修复[1]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 1.4 UEFI... The Microsoft Kill Switch (www.learnlinuxandlibreoffice.org)
Content: As if the insanity of handing the keys to our computers over to Microsoft was not bad enough, in June 2016, two computer security researchers discovered that Microsoft was doing some rather reckless things with these Golden Keys. Microsoft developers wanted to make changes to certain devices without going through the hassle of getting authorized keys to Secure Boot. So they developed a secret “super policy” for bypassing Secure Boot completely. Had this Golden Key “super policy” been discovered by hackers it would have given them unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world. The only good news to this story is that this backdoor nuclear weapon was discovered by “Good Guy” researchers before it was discovered by Bad Guy hackers. https://www.infoworld.com/article/3106079/security/secure-boot-proves-insecurity-of-backdoors.html


After the researchers notified Microsoft of the issue, the company released a security patch MS16-094 in July 2016. This “golden key” super policy is now blocked from loading on computers with the July patch installed. However, the July patch is not a complete fix -- it's at most a small roadblock. The issue remains only partially addressed, and what's worse, it is believed that it is impossible for Microsoft to fully revoke the leaked Golden Key Super policy.


[Image: 1.4.09]


Because of the implications of this Golden Key Backdoor being released to the wild, the two researchers wrote a letter to the FBI explaining why the entire concept of having super keys to all computers was a bad idea:


“Microsoft implemented a 'secure golden key' system. And the golden keys got released by Microsoft's own stupidity. Now, what happens if you tell everyone to make a 'secure golden key' system? This is a perfect real-world example about why your idea of backdooring cryptosystems with a 'golden key' is very bad!”


The first lesson we should learn from the 2016 Golden Key incident is that keys and secrets will eventually get leaked or stolen. The second lesson is that a fix is not always possible.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Microsoft Leaks Secure Boot Key, Raises Security Concerns (www.informationweek.com)
Content: Microsoft is causing major cyber-security concerns with the accidental leak of a "golden key" intended to protect devices equipped with Secure Boot.


The Secure Boot feature is intended to protect Windows devices by making sure they only use software trusted by the PC maker or user. It's part of Microsoft's Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and ensures each component loaded during the boot process is validated.


The all-access keys were discovered by MY123 and Slipstream in March 2016. A recent blog post (animated site with tinny, arcade-style music) by researchers at MY123 and Slipstream dives into the details of Microsoft's security problems and the errors it made in addressing them.


[Google: QuadRooter threat is blocked on most Android devices.]


Note that the golden key isn't an actual key, but a means of changing the tasks launched by UEFI during the boot process, as explained in a report by Ars Technica. The policy has been made available online. It will enable anyone to disable the Secure Boot feature.


Secure Boot can be disabled on several types of desktop PCs, but is hard-coded into most devices running Windows. It seems the golden key is intended to turn off OS checks so programmers can test new projects. However, it can also leave Windows devices vulnerable.


The keys leaked by Microsoft will allow users with admin rights to install any operating system -- like Linux or Android -- on their Windows PCs, smartphones, or tablets.
---

question_src: 是什么防止海洋淹没地球？
all_claims: 海洋之所以没有淹没地球，根本原因在于地壳“轻重不均”造成的两级地形：较轻、厚而富含硅铝的大陆地壳因浮力效应上浮，形成高于海平面的大陆；较重、薄而富含铁镁的岩石下沉，形成深达数千米的海盆，专门“容纳”海水[1]。
因此全球表面呈现出大陆与四大海盆（北冰洋、大西洋、印度洋、太平洋）相间分布的格局[2]。
当水分通过蒸发–凝结–降水循环在海陆间迁移时，降到陆地上的水因地势高差最终沿河流回流入海盆[3]；即使地幔持续少量释放新水，也会优先充填海盆而非漫过大陆高地[1]。
这种由差异密度塑造的“天然水槽”加上水循环的自动回流机制，共同防止了海洋漫过陆地，保持了今日约三成陆地、七成海洋的星球外貌。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: All About the Ocean (www.nationalgeographic.org)
Content: After the Earth began to form about 4.6 billion years ago, it gradually separated into layers of lighter and heavier rock. The lighter rock rose and formed the Earth’s crust. The heavier rock sank and formed the Earth’s core and mantle.


The ocean’s water came from rocks inside the newly forming Earth. As the molten rocks cooled, they released water vapor and other gases. Eventually, the water vapor condensed and covered the crust with a primitive ocean. Today, hot gases from the Earth’s interior continue to produce new water at the bottom of the ocean.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Oceans. Formation of the Oceans. Facts about the Oceans (encyclopedia.lubopitko-bg.com)
Content: The largest features of the Earth's surface are the continents and ocean basins. The four major ocean basins (Arctic, Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific) are bound by landmasses and major oceanic ridges. Each continent is rimmed by a submerged, gently sloping continental margin. This includes the relatively flat continental shelf, generally found at depths of less than 600 feet (183 meters) with a width of a few miles to more than 200 miles (322 kilometers). At the shelf break portion of the margin, there is a rise in the continental shelf before the continental slope begins its plunge to the deep-sea bottom. Deep submarine canyons frequently cut into the continental margin.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: The Water Cycle (oceantoday.noaa.gov)
Content: Over 96% of total global water is in the ocean, so let’s start there. Energy from the sun causes water on the surface to evaporate into water vapor – a gas. This invisible vapor rises into the atmosphere, where the air is colder, and condenses into clouds. Air currents move these clouds all around the earth.


Water drops form in clouds, and the drops then return to the ocean or land as precipitation - let’s say this time, it’s snow. The snow will fall to the ground, and eventually melts back into a liquid and runs off into a lake or river, which flows back into the ocean, where it starts the process again.
---

question_src: 为什么总是以“ .99”而不是“ .00”结尾的项目？
all_claims: 商家把价格设为“.99”而非“.00”是一种心理定价策略，利用人们对数字的直觉反应来提升购买率[1]。
由于我们自左向右阅读，最先看到的数字最能吸引注意，4.99 美元给人的第一印象仍是“四元多”，因此比5.00 美元看上去便宜，消费者更可能下单[2]。
同时，大脑倾向于把9.99归入9–9.99这一较低“类别”，而不是10–10.99的区间，即使只差一分钱也产生显著的心理落差[1]。
购物者在快速决策时往往懒得深究小数点后的数字，从而进一步放大了这一差距[2]。
此外，多数人已被训练成看到“.99”就联想到特价或打折，这种“正在促销”的暗示感也推高了成交概率[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: The Real Reason Most Prices End in .99 (www.rd.com)
Content: Prices are more likely to end in .99 more than any other pair of numbers—and certainly more than the even .00. We probably don’t think twice about buying something for $5.99 or $16.99, but it is a little strange when you think about it. Why aren’t prices just even dollar amounts? Is it an elaborate marketing scheme to get you to spend more?

Well, essentially…yes. But there’s really nothing “elaborate” about it; it’s actually pretty simple. “It’s a type of psychological pricing,” says Julie Ramhold, consumer analyst with DealNews.com. “Because we read from left to right, we pay less attention to the end of the number versus the beginning.” This is especially effective if you’re just quickly perusing several prices in a row; the first number will definitely stand out to you more. Psychological pricing is powerful, but luckily, there are also plenty of psychology tricks to help you spend less while shopping.

Of course, we still know that $9.99 is basically ten dollars, not nine dollars. But the $.99 trick takes advantage of the way our brains process prices. When we see a price of $9.99, we associate it as part of the $9–$9.99 “range” rather than the $10–$10.99 “range.” “Consumers don’t want to transcend a certain category, so even a penny less may make a huge psychological difference,” explains Subimal Chatterjee, Distinguished Teaching Professor of Marketing at Binghamton University School of Management.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Do Most Prices End in .99? (www.livescience.com)
Content: Ending a price in .99 is based on the theory that, because we read from left to right, the first digit of the price resonates with us the most, Hibbett explained. That's why shoppers are more likely to buy a product for $4.99 than an identical one for $5 the item that starts with a 4 just seems like a better deal than the one that starts with 5.

"We also tend to attempt to reduce the amount of effort expended on making product decisions, especially with lower-cost items," Hibbett told Life's Little Mysteries. "So we may not really process the numbers after the dollar amount."

Additionally, the .99 alone serves to make an item appear to be on sale, according to the article "Mind Your Pricing Cues," published in the September 2003 issue of the Harvard Business Review. Price-conscious consumers have become conditioned to believe that they are getting a good deal when they buy something with a price ending in .99 even if the markdown is minimal.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: The Real Reason Most Prices End in .99 (www.rd.com)
Content: Prices are more likely to end in .99 more than any other pair of numbers—and certainly more than the even .00. We probably don’t think twice about buying something for $5.99 or $16.99, but it is a little strange when you think about it. Why aren’t prices just even dollar amounts? Is it an elaborate marketing scheme to get you to spend more?

Well, essentially…yes. But there’s really nothing “elaborate” about it; it’s actually pretty simple. “It’s a type of psychological pricing,” says Julie Ramhold, consumer analyst with DealNews.com. “Because we read from left to right, we pay less attention to the end of the number versus the beginning.” This is especially effective if you’re just quickly perusing several prices in a row; the first number will definitely stand out to you more. Psychological pricing is powerful, but luckily, there are also plenty of psychology tricks to help you spend less while shopping.

Of course, we still know that $9.99 is basically ten dollars, not nine dollars. But the $.99 trick takes advantage of the way our brains process prices. When we see a price of $9.99, we associate it as part of the $9–$9.99 “range” rather than the $10–$10.99 “range.” “Consumers don’t want to transcend a certain category, so even a penny less may make a huge psychological difference,” explains Subimal Chatterjee, Distinguished Teaching Professor of Marketing at Binghamton University School of Management.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Do Most Prices End in .99? (www.livescience.com)
Content: Ending a price in .99 is based on the theory that, because we read from left to right, the first digit of the price resonates with us the most, Hibbett explained. That's why shoppers are more likely to buy a product for $4.99 than an identical one for $5 the item that starts with a 4 just seems like a better deal than the one that starts with 5.

"We also tend to attempt to reduce the amount of effort expended on making product decisions, especially with lower-cost items," Hibbett told Life's Little Mysteries. "So we may not really process the numbers after the dollar amount."

Additionally, the .99 alone serves to make an item appear to be on sale, according to the article "Mind Your Pricing Cues," published in the September 2003 issue of the Harvard Business Review. Price-conscious consumers have become conditioned to believe that they are getting a good deal when they buy something with a price ending in .99 even if the markdown is minimal.
---

question_src: 我妈妈刚刚告诉我，大多数股票都不付钱。是这样吗？如果是这样，为什么股票市场甚至存在，我们都同意做一个赌博领域，我们押注其他人押注我们的赌注？如果是这样，为什么公司对股东有多重要？
all_claims: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东[2]。
即便没有股息，投资者仍可通过公司盈利扩张带来的股价上涨获利，因此股票市场并非纯粹“押注别人押注”——它让企业获得长期资本，投资人获得分享企业成果与资产增值的权利。
赌博和投资都冒风险，但赌场游戏从长期看预期回报为负，而股票市场历史平均预期收益率则为正[5]；投资者还能通过研究、分散化等方式识别并管理风险[4]。
公司之所以重视股东，是因为股东提供的资金支持研发、扩产及并购；作为所有者，股东可凭投票权影响董事会、在公司分红或清算时分配剩余资产，这套产权与治理机制正是现代经济持续扩张的基础。
claims_retained: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How and When Are Stock Dividends Paid Out? (www.investopedia.com)
Content: A dividend is the distribution of some of a company's earnings to a class of its shareholders. Dividends are usually paid in the form of a dividend check. However, they may also be paid in additional shares of stock. The standard practice for the payment of dividends is a check that is mailed to stockholders a few days after the ex-dividend date, which is the date on which the stock starts trading without the previously declared dividend.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Do All Stocks Have Dividends? (Why Don’t Some Stocks Pay Dividends?) (therobusttrader.com)
Content: All stocks do not pay a dividend. Profitable companies’ managers have the option of either compensating shareholders directly (through a dividend), or investing back into the company to fuel growth and increase the value of the company. Because of this, investors have the option to either go for dividend-paying stocks or stocks which emphasize growth over shareholder compensation.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Content: Gambling, trading, speculation, and investment are perceived in very different ways but they have two core similarities. First, they all involve risking money in hopes of a positive return. Second, the results are dependent in part on luck.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Content: A number of distinctions between the various endeavors are usually drawn. Gambling is typically viewed as a form of entertainment that carries a higher level of risk and has a less certain outcome. Speculation and investment are generally viewed as business enterprises in which risk is understood and steps are taking to mitigate and manage it.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Going All-In: Investing vs. Gambling (www.investopedia.com)
Content: True, investing and gambling both involve risk and choice—specifically, the risk of capital with hopes of future profit. But gambling is typically a short-lived activity, while equities investing can last a lifetime. Also, there is a negative expected return to gamblers, on average and over the long run. On the other hand, investing in the stock market typically carries with it a positive expected return on average over the long run.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: Snapchat uses end-to-end encryption on photos shared between its users. Text messages and other messages sent on Snapchat aren’t protected by the same encryption. Snapchat doesn’t disclose much information about the type of encryption that it uses, so it can be difficult to truly understand what happens to your messages once they get to Snap’s servers.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: Don’t Let People Find You with Your Mobile Number: Snapchat settings allow you to toggle whether or not other users can find your Snapchat account using your mobile number. If you are concerned about privacy, you should turn this feature off. If you use your personal cell phone number for work purposes, or have your phone number published anywhere online, turning this off can protect you from an unwanted flood of unknown people adding you as a friend.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: The truth is, however, that whenever a user opens the Snapchat app, their location is shared on the Snap Map. Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
Content: When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: Snapchat uses end-to-end encryption on photos shared between its users. Text messages and other messages sent on Snapchat aren’t protected by the same encryption. Snapchat doesn’t disclose much information about the type of encryption that it uses, so it can be difficult to truly understand what happens to your messages once they get to Snap’s servers.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: Don’t Let People Find You with Your Mobile Number: Snapchat settings allow you to toggle whether or not other users can find your Snapchat account using your mobile number. If you are concerned about privacy, you should turn this feature off. If you use your personal cell phone number for work purposes, or have your phone number published anywhere online, turning this off can protect you from an unwanted flood of unknown people adding you as a friend.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: The truth is, however, that whenever a user opens the Snapchat app, their location is shared on the Snap Map. Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
Content: When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.
---

question_src: 贝宝（PayPal），如果值得信赖/值得，我应该得到它吗？
all_claims: 贝宝采用全站加密技术，保护客户在网上购物时的数据与资金安全，这为其可信度奠定基础[1]；用户用银行账户或余额在美国境内付款无需费用，而用信用/借记卡支付则需收取2.9%＋0.30美元的手续费[2]，对普通买家相对友好。
卖家方面，标准收费同样是2.9%＋0.30美元[4]，费率透明，且可根据需求选择个人、Premier 或企业账户，后两者取消500美元月提取上限并支持多种支付方式[4]。
若需迅速套现，PayPal提供“即时转移”到银行账户或借记卡，速度快但需额外费用；若不急，可选择1–3个工作日的标准转移免手续费[3]。
此外，eBay 等大型平台要求商家支持所有形式的PayPal支付，并且付款通常即时到账[5]，显示其在电子商务生态中的广泛接受度。
综合来看，PayPal在安全性、高覆盖率及基本免费收款方面表现出色，但若频繁使用信用卡或需要即时提现，其手续费值得权衡；因此，如您常进行跨平台网络交易且能合理安排资金流，PayPal是一个值得拥有的支付工具。

Title: How Does PayPal Work? - NerdWallet (www.nerdwallet.com)
Content: Fees: $0 to make a purchase or transfer money domestically using a bank account or your PayPal balance. 2.9% of the amount, plus 30 cents, to transfer funds using a credit card, debit card, or PayPal credit.

Transfer limits: Varies, $4,000-$60,000 per transaction.

Content: ### Instant Transfer


If time is of the essence, move money now from PayPal to your eligible bank account or debit card for a fee.


### Standard Transfer


If your money can wait, get it in 1-3 business days at no additional cost.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How Does PayPal Work for Sellers? (yourbusiness.azcentral.com)
Content: There are three primary types of PayPal account, and sellers can accept payments with any of them. A Personal account allows a seller to receive payments from other PayPal users, but has a withdrawal limit of $500 per month. Connecting a bank account or credit card allows a seller to upgrade to a Premier account, which removes this limit and offers the ability to accept credit and debit card payments as well. A Business account is the same as a Premier account, but allows access by multiple users. The standard fee for selling via PayPal is 2.9 percent plus 30 cents per transaction.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Getting paid with PayPal (www.ebay.com)
Content: You need a Paypal account in order to use PayPal to receive payment for eBay sales. If you don’t have an account, we’ll ask you to sign up when you create your first listing.


When you create a listing, select PayPal as a payment method and enter the email address associated with your PayPal account in the Payment options section of the listing form.


Remember, if you offer PayPal as a payment option on eBay (using either logos or text in the item description), you must accept all forms of PayPal payment, including payments from an existing PayPal account balance, bank account transfers, and credit card payments. You can’t tell buyers that you only accept specific forms of PayPal payment. See the Payment methods policy for more information. When a buyer sends you a payment through PayPal, the money is usually available in your PayPal account right away.

claim: 美国总统选举采用选举人团制度，这是建国先贤在由国会选总统与全民直选之间折衷的产物。
question_src: 美国总统选举制度。我不明白这一点。
all_claims: 美国总统选举采用选举人团制度，这是建国先贤在由国会选总统与全民直选之间折衷的产物[2]。
全国共有538名选举人，每州人数等于其众议员席位数加两名参议员，哥伦比亚特区另得3名选举人，赢得过半即270票即可当选总统[4]。
选民在11月大选日投出的其实是各州承诺支持某候选人的选举人名单，而非直接投给候选人本人[3]。
48个州与华盛顿特区实行“胜者全得”，普选领先者获得该州全部选举人票；缅因州和内布拉斯加州则按比例分配选举人票[1]。
选举夜通常依据统计宣布“预计获胜者”，真正的选举人团投票要到12月中旬各州选举人集会时进行[1]。
宪法虽未强制选举人遵守州内普选结果，一些州法律却要求如此，违者可能被罚款、撤换甚至起诉，因此所谓“失信选举人”极为罕见[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
Content: After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: The Founding Fathers created the Electoral College system as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by the popular vote of qualified citizens.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: Each state gets a number of electors equal to its number of members in the U.S. House of Representatives plus one for each of its two U.S. senators. The District of Columbia gets three electors.﻿﻿ State laws determine how electors are chosen, but they are generally selected by the political party committees within the states.


Each elector gets one vote. Thus, a state with eight electors would cast eight votes. As of the 1964 election, there are 538 electors, and the votes of a majority of them—270—are required to be elected.﻿﻿ Because Electoral College representation is based on congressional representation, states with larger populations get more Electoral College votes.
---

Title: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
Content: After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.

Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: The Founding Fathers created the Electoral College system as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by the popular vote of qualified citizens.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: Each state gets a number of electors equal to its number of members in the U.S. House of Representatives plus one for each of its two U.S. senators. The District of Columbia gets three electors.﻿﻿ State laws determine how electors are chosen, but they are generally selected by the political party committees within the states.


Each elector gets one vote. Thus, a state with eight electors would cast eight votes. As of the 1964 election, there are 538 electors, and the votes of a majority of them—270—are required to be elected.﻿﻿ Because Electoral College representation is based on congressional representation, states with larger populations get more Electoral College votes.
---

进入深度睡眠后，人体肌肉活动被抑制，身体几乎不动，曲线因此趋于平坦，系统就把这一段识别为深睡或熟睡[1]；若检测到连续较大的翻身或起床动作，则会被标记为浅睡、清醒或中断[3]。
应用通过整夜各时间段的“运动强度—持续时间”模式来估算你入睡、浅睡、深睡和醒来的时间，从而判断“你什么时候在睡觉”。
需要注意的是，任何非睡眠的剧烈动作（例如拿手机、起身喝水）都可能被记录成睡眠不安或中断，因而仍存在一定误差[3]。

question_src: 作为一个有散光的人，为什么当我有点斜视我的眼睛时，我会看到更清晰的东西呢？
all_claims: 散光时角膜弯曲不均，光线无法在视网膜形成单一点成像而出现重影和模糊。
眯眼会收窄眼裂、缩小瞳孔，只让靠近光轴的少量中央光线进入，相当于在眼前加了“针孔”，屏蔽了原本偏离焦点的周边光线，于是视野变得锐利，这就是针孔效应[2]。
同时，眼睑压力与眼肌紧张使晶状体曲率略增，相当于微调镜头焦距，使光线更好地汇聚于视网膜[1]。
两种机制叠加，可让散光者暂时看得更清晰，但并不能替代专业验光与矫正。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Can I See Better When I Squint My Eyes? - Grosinger, Spigelman & Grey (www.eyemichigan.com)
Content: What Does Squinting Do to Your Eye?


Even though it doesn’t feel much different, squinting does three things to our eyes that lead to slightly clearer vision.


* Our Eye Lens Changes Shape – The lens of the eye is flexible and changes shape when we squint.
* The Eye Lens Adjusts – Small adjustments in the lens allow us to focus better, much like a camera.
* Less Light Enters the Eye – Less light enters, reducing the impact on the retina and allowing the object we view to look sharper.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Do I See Better When I Squint? (www.invision2020.com)
Content: A small amount of the increased clarity of vision is due to changing the shape of the eye as you squint. However, the main optical principle at work, and one that is quite fascinating, is called the “pinhole effect”. Clear vision is a result of light rays that properly focused on the retina located in the back of the eye. Typically, this is done with glasses or contact lenses; both of which bend light into focus and therefore correct vision.


When we squint it creates the same effect as looking through a pinhole. Basically only a small amount of focused central light rays are allowed into the eye. This prevents the unfocused light rays in the periphery from reaching the retina. The result is better vision. Photographers understand this as “depth of field”.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Vision Hack: How to See Clearly Without Your Glasses or Contacts (vision-and-hearing.wonderhowto.com)
Content: The reason that squinting helps you see is because it changes the shape of your eye, making the pupil smaller, thus letting less light in and making an image clear. This is similar to the way a larger aperture works; a smaller hole in your camera lets less light in, with better focus.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Cornell Center for Materials Research (www.ccmr.cornell.edu)
Content: By limiting the rays of light that come in through the bottom and top of the pupil, squinting allows rays to pass closer to the center of the lens, thereby creating a more focused image. So, that means that squinting works by two mechanisms – by both changing the shape of the eye and by letting in light that can be focused more precisely by the lens.
---

claim: 每天约有48吨太空碎屑坠入大气，其中绝大多数在高空就以尘埃或微小流星体的形式烧毁，对大气和地表几乎无害。
question_src: 流星（或其他空间碎片）会损害或对大气层造成风险吗？如果是这样，对我们有多危险？如果不是，为什么不呢？
all_claims: 每天约有48吨太空碎屑坠入大气，其中绝大多数在高空就以尘埃或微小流星体的形式烧毁，对大气和地表几乎无害[1]。
当较小流星进入大气时，高温和动压常使其瓦解，甚至因空气渗入多孔内部而“从内而外”爆炸成碎片，进一步降低落地危害[4]。
然而若撞击体直径达到约1–2公里，就足以抛射大量蒸发尘土遮蔽阳光，在全球范围内引发多年“撞击冬天”并扰乱气候[2]。
待尘埃沉降，大量温室气体与撞击火灾产生的气溶胶又会导致显著增温，形成长期气候变暖[2]。
此外，撞击输入的巨大能量能破坏平流层臭氧层，使地表紫外线强度大增，持续约两年，危及人类健康与生态[3]。
因此，日常流星对大气几乎无风险，但极少数大型小行星若撞击则可能带来灾难性全球环境变化。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Long Term Effects of an Asteroid Impact on Earth (education.seattlepi.com)
Content: It may seem like meteors crashing to Earth are rare, but more than 48 tons of debris falls into Earth's atmosphere every single day. Most of this comes in the form of dust and micrometeorites that burn up instantly, but on rare occasions, larger rocks may fall into the planet's gravity well. Depending on the size of the object, an impact can cause a number of different effects, and a large enough asteroid could drastically change life on Earth.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Long Term Effects of an Asteroid Impact on Earth (education.seattlepi.com)
Content: A massive asteroid impact would create long-term changes in the atmosphere and climate of the planet. Upon impact, vaporized dirt and rock would fill the atmosphere, blocking sunlight and creating a state of near-permanent darkness and winter-like conditions. After the particles in the atmosphere settle, an increase in greenhouse gases from impact fires and released stores in the crater area could actually increase temperatures substantially due to an increased greenhouse effect. The severity and length of each of these phases would depend on the size of the impact, with a one or two kilometer-wide asteroid causing enough damage to trigger worldwide disturbances for years.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Long Term Effects of an Asteroid Impact on Earth (education.seattlepi.com)
Content: Another dangerous effect of an asteroid strike would be damage to the ozone layer. The energy imparted to the atmosphere by the incoming object would be enough to disrupt the protective layer of ozone high in the stratosphere, drastically increasing the amount of ultraviolet light that made it to the surface. This would increase global cancer rates, affect the growth of plants and animals and possibly lead to genetic mutations over the period of increased exposure. Depending on the size of the asteroid, this could last for as much as two years.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
Content: Earth's atmosphere may infiltrate the interior of porous meteors as they hurtle toward the planet, creating pockets of high-pressure air inside the rocky space debris. These pockets can then cause the space rocks to explode, breaking into smaller pieces.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
Content: When meteors enter the planet's atmosphere, they heat up, and ultimately disintegrate. (This is either because of something -called ram pressure or friction.). However, the new research highlights a new way in which the atmosphere may break up meteors and protect Earth, the researchers said.
---

claim: 在加密领域，“位”(bit)是构成密钥的二进制数字；每个位只能取 0 或 1，是计算与通信中最基本的数据单位。
question_src: 关于加密，“位”是什么意思？即4096位加密
all_claims: 在加密领域，“位”(bit)是构成密钥的二进制数字；每个位只能取 0 或 1，是计算与通信中最基本的数据单位[1]。
密钥长度用位数表示，n 位密钥拥有 2ⁿ 种可能组合，位数越多，穷举破解的难度呈指数级增加，因此“4096 位加密”通常指采用 4096 位长的 RSA 密钥，其长度比常见的 2048 位密钥更大，安全性也更高[5]。
一张常用对照表表明，大约 2048 位 RSA 提供约 112 位对称安全强度，3072 位约 128 位，7680 位约 192 位[4]；4096 位处于 3072 与 7680 之间，通常被视为满足长期高安全需求的选项，但其运算成本也相应上升——在 RSA 中密钥长度每翻倍，解密速度大约变慢 5 倍[5]。
claims_retained: 在加密领域，“位”(bit)是构成密钥的二进制数字；每个位只能取 0 或 1，是计算与通信中最基本的数据单位[1]。
密钥长度用位数表示，n 位密钥拥有 2ⁿ 种可能组合，位数越多，穷举破解的难度呈指数级增加，因此“4096 位加密”通常指采用 4096 位长的 RSA 密钥，其长度比常见的 2048 位密钥更大，安全性也更高[5]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Bit (www.techopedia.com)
Content: A bit, short for binary digit, is defined as the most basic unit of data in telecommunications and computing. Each bit is represented by either a 1 or a 0 and this can be executed in various systems through a two-state device.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Bit (www.techopedia.com)
Content: A computer not only initiates multiple instructions that can manipulate and test bits, but it also performs these instructions and stores accumulated data in eight-bit parcels called bytes
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What does BIT mean? (www.definitions.net)
Content: The length of a binary number may be referred to as its bit-length. In information theory, one bit is typically defined as the uncertainty of a binary random variable that is 0 or 1 with equal probability
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Should We Start Using 4096 bit RSA keys? (www.jscape.com)
Content: Security Strength RSA key length
<= 80 1024
112 2048
128 3072
192 7680
256 15360
---
Document ID: 5
Title: RSA key lengths (www.javamex.com)
Content: * unless you can accept a relatively low level of security and are running on modest hardware, you should generally choose an RSA key length of at least 2048 bits (current NIST recommendation);
* if you are running on recent dedicated hardware and/or require good security, then consider a key size of 4096 bits;
* you could consider higher key lengths, but the performance overhead increase almost exponentially with key length, meaning in practice a doubling of key length makes decryption some 5 times slower
---

密钥长度用位数表示，n 位密钥拥有 2ⁿ 种可能组合，位数越多，穷举破解的难度呈指数级增加，因此“4096 位加密”通常指采用 4096 位长的 RSA 密钥，其长度比常见的 2048 位密钥更大，安全性也更高[5]。

* if you are running on recent dedicated hardware and/or require good security, then consider a key size of 4096 bits;
* you could consider higher key lengths, but the performance overhead increase almost exponentially with key length, meaning in practice a doubling of key length makes decryption some 5 times slower

claim: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越 。
question_src: 为什么在大多数情况下，S等级高？
all_claims: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越 [2]。
由于这一做法明确传达了 “比 A 还好” 的概念，S 很快被游戏、动漫、武术排行等流行文化借用，作为超越常规等级的象征，在排名表或关卡评价中代表“最高”“最强” [1]。
因此，人们习惯把 S 视为顶点，不论是在学术、竞技还是娱乐评分里，都用它来标榜极少数达到“特别（Special/Super）”或“优胜（Superior）”标准的对象。
claims_retained: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越 [2]。

claim: 过去50年来，数字技术以指数速度演进，其核心动力是摩尔定律：集成电路上的晶体管数量大约每两年翻倍。
question_src: 在过去的50年中，技术增长如何呈指数增长？
all_claims: 过去50年来，数字技术以指数速度演进，其核心动力是摩尔定律：集成电路上的晶体管数量大约每两年翻倍[1]。
1965年戈登·摩尔基于这一观察预测，计算性能将指数式提升、成本则同步下降[2]。
实际发展证明，晶体管尺寸不断缩小，使得在相同面积内可容纳的晶体管数量急剧增加，带来处理速度提升和能效改善，同时终端价格持续走低[2]。
这种指数增长不仅让电脑、手机等既有产品性能飞跃，还催生云计算、社交媒体和现代数据分析等全新产业[2]。
在硬件层面，存储容量、相机像素等指标也遵循类似翻倍轨迹，显示技术各方面都在指数扩张[1]。
粗略估算，自1965年至今经历约25次翻倍，计算能力提升超过千万倍，促成计算从稀缺昂贵的资源演变为普及且廉价的社会基础设施，从而深刻改变了工作、娱乐与交流方式。

1965年戈登·摩尔基于这一观察预测，计算性能将指数式提升、成本则同步下降[2]。

在硬件层面，存储容量、相机像素等指标也遵循类似翻倍轨迹，显示技术各方面都在指数扩张[1]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Technological Progress (ourworldindata.org)
Content: Moore’s Law is the observation that the number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years. This aspect of technological progress is important as the capabilities of many digital electronic devices are strongly linked to Moore’s Law. Below I will show how aspects as diverse as processing speed, product price, memory capacity, and even the number and size of pixels in digital cameras have also been progressing exponentially.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Over 50 Years of Moore's Law (www.intel.com)
Content: In 1965, Gordon Moore made a prediction that would set the pace for our modern digital revolution. From careful observation of an emerging trend, Moore extrapolated that computing would dramatically increase in power, and decrease in relative cost, at an exponential pace. The insight, known as Moore’s Law, became the golden rule for the electronics industry, and a springboard for innovation. As a co-founder, Gordon paved the path for Intel to make the ever faster, smaller, more affordable transistors that drive our modern tools and toys. Even over 50 years later, the lasting impact and benefits are felt in many ways.


### Economic Impact


### Economic Impact


Performance—aka power—and cost are two key drivers of technological development. As more transistors fit into smaller spaces, processing power increased and energy efficiency improved, all at a lower cost for the end user. This development not only enhanced existing industries and increased productivity, but it has spawned whole new industries empowered by cheap and powerful computing.


### Technological Impact


### Technological Impact


Moore’s observation transformed computing from a rare and expensive venture into a pervasive and affordable necessity. All of the modern computing technology we know and enjoy sprang from the foundation laid by Moore’s Law. From the Internet itself, to social media and modern data analytics, all these innovations stem directly from Moore and his findings.


### Societal Impact


### Societal Impact


The inexpensive, ubiquitous computing rapidly expanding all around us is fundamentally changing the way we work, play and communicate. The foundational force of Moore’s Law has driven breakthroughs in modern cities, transportation, healthcare, education, and energy production.
---

实际发展证明，晶体管尺寸不断缩小，使得在相同面积内可容纳的晶体管数量急剧增加，带来处理速度提升和能效改善，同时终端价格持续走低[2]。
这种指数增长不仅让电脑、手机等既有产品性能飞跃，还催生云计算、社交媒体和现代数据分析等全新产业[2]。
在硬件层面，存储容量、相机像素等指标也遵循类似翻倍轨迹，显示技术各方面都在指数扩张[1]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Technological Progress (ourworldindata.org)
Content: Moore’s Law is the observation that the number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years. This aspect of technological progress is important as the capabilities of many digital electronic devices are strongly linked to Moore’s Law. Below I will show how aspects as diverse as processing speed, product price, memory capacity, and even the number and size of pixels in digital cameras have also been progressing exponentially.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Over 50 Years of Moore's Law (www.intel.com)
Content: In 1965, Gordon Moore made a prediction that would set the pace for our modern digital revolution. From careful observation of an emerging trend, Moore extrapolated that computing would dramatically increase in power, and decrease in relative cost, at an exponential pace. The insight, known as Moore’s Law, became the golden rule for the electronics industry, and a springboard for innovation. As a co-founder, Gordon paved the path for Intel to make the ever faster, smaller, more affordable transistors that drive our modern tools and toys. Even over 50 years later, the lasting impact and benefits are felt in many ways.


### Economic Impact


### Economic Impact


Performance—aka power—and cost are two key drivers of technological development. As more transistors fit into smaller spaces, processing power increased and energy efficiency improved, all at a lower cost for the end user. This development not only enhanced existing industries and increased productivity, but it has spawned whole new industries empowered by cheap and powerful computing.


### Technological Impact


### Technological Impact


Moore’s observation transformed computing from a rare and expensive venture into a pervasive and affordable necessity. All of the modern computing technology we know and enjoy sprang from the foundation laid by Moore’s Law. From the Internet itself, to social media and modern data analytics, all these innovations stem directly from Moore and his findings.


### Societal Impact


### Societal Impact


The inexpensive, ubiquitous computing rapidly expanding all around us is fundamentally changing the way we work, play and communicate. The foundational force of Moore’s Law has driven breakthroughs in modern cities, transportation, healthcare, education, and energy production.
---
Using the above information, the response is the answer to the query or task: "在过去的50年中，技术增长如何呈指数增长？" in a single sentence.

claim: 若碎片轨道稍远，重力凝聚可形成一颗或多颗卫星。
question_src: 为什么有些行星形成环而其他行星则形成卫星？
all_claims: 行星周围的物质命运取决于距离、温度和行星质量：若碎片位于行星罗什极限附近，强潮汐力阻止其聚成大块，只能维持为颗粒轨道结构，即环系[2]。
若碎片轨道稍远，重力凝聚可形成一颗或多颗卫星[2]。
环多由冰尘组成，靠近太阳的内行星环境过热，冰无法长期存在，因而难保留大环，而远离太阳的巨行星低温使冰尘稳定[1]。
巨行星质量大，早期吸积了丰富的气体、尘埃和冰，不仅为规则卫星提供“建材”，也能捕获过境小天体成为不规则卫星，而内侧岩质行星周围材料稀少，往往只能在偶发碰撞后抛射物质形成单一大月，如地月系[3]。
因此，环或卫星的出现，是行星引力、轨道位置、成分与形成史共同作用的结果。
claims_retained: 若碎片轨道稍远，重力凝聚可形成一颗或多颗卫星[2]。
环多由冰尘组成，靠近太阳的内行星环境过热，冰无法长期存在，因而难保留大环，而远离太阳的巨行星低温使冰尘稳定[1]。
巨行星质量大，早期吸积了丰富的气体、尘埃和冰，不仅为规则卫星提供“建材”，也能捕获过境小天体成为不规则卫星，而内侧岩质行星周围材料稀少，往往只能在偶发碰撞后抛射物质形成单一大月，如地月系[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Content: There's actually still scientific dispute about the exact answer to this question. The solar system formed from a giant cloud of gas and particles (literally stardust--the remains of a star that had exploded) billions of years ago. The "dust" clumped together to form the planets. Some of the leftover dust formed the moons of the planets (although the origin of Earth's moon is still up for debate). Some of this dust was too close to the planet to form stable moons, and instead formed rings. It is likely that large rings couldn't form on inner planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars) because the rings are made of frozen icy dust, and the sun is too hot this close to it for the rings to form.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Curiosities: Why do some planets have rings? (news.wisc.edu)
Content: “There are various theories about planetary rings, like the fantastic rings around Saturn, but we cannot say for sure how they are formed,” explains Lattis.


One theory is that the rings formed at the same time as the planet and its major moons. In this case, if material is close to the planet, the planet’s gravitational pull is too strong to coalesce into a moon and the particles that would otherwise form a moon spread out in orbit around the planet as a ring.


Another idea is that a close call by a moon or comet results in the planet’s gravitational tidal force breaking up those bodies, the debris of which then becomes a ring system.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Deanna Rostic, St. Catharines, Ontario, Canada (astronomy.com)
Content: The larger volume of space and lower gravity of the Sun in the giant-planet region allowed Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune to form like solar systems in miniature. We think each of them pulled in lots of material and had a disk of gas, dust, and ice surrounding it during formation. Any dust and ice not incorporated into the planet itself would have coalesced into the regular moons we see today around the giant planets. These satellites are in nearly circular orbits near the equators of their host planets, such as the four Galilean satellites around Jupiter and Titan around Saturn, which are all composed of large fractions of ice.


Because the giant planets gravitationally dominate a very large area, they also can efficiently capture passing objects as moons, which we call irregular satellites. These irregular moons are relatively small and have orbits with large inclinations, eccentricities, and semimajor axes.


In contrast, the terrestrial planets formed much closer to the Sun with much less material around them. They grew slowly by accreting many small rocky planetesimals and never grew massive enough to capture a disk of gas and dust. Earth’s Moon probably formed through a direct collision. Any large object striking a planet would have thrown material off the world into orbit, allowing it to coalesce into a moon.
---

claim: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定。
question_src: 为什么太阳能系统看起来主要是“平坦”？
all_claims: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定[1]。
当云中的尘埃和气体不断相互碰撞时，粒子虽可向任意方向移动，但垂直于旋转平面的上行与下行运动相互抵消，使系统逐渐失去高度[1]。
随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘[2]。
这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。
claims_retained: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定[1]。
当云中的尘埃和气体不断相互碰撞时，粒子虽可向任意方向移动，但垂直于旋转平面的上行与下行运动相互抵消，使系统逐渐失去高度[1]。
随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘[2]。
这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Is The Solar System Flat? (www.scienceabc.com)
Content: The flatness of our solar system can be ascribed to the law of conservation of total angular momentum. Due to this, whenever particles collide, they may move in any direction, but all the up and down motion cancels out, always following the rule that the total spin in that plane must be constant.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why is the Solar System flat? – How It Works (www.howitworksdaily.com)
Content: This is due to a rule known as the conservation of angular momentum – the total amount of spinning in any isolated system, such as the Solar System, will always remain constant. This allowed the cloud to flatten over time, losing its height and becoming the roughly two-dimensional disc we see today.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Discover how the solar system, which started as a shapeless spherical blob ended up being flat (www.britannica.com)
Content: As the particles bump into each other, all the up and down motion tends to cancel out, it's energy lost in crashing and clumping. Yet, the whole mass must continue spinning, inexorably, because in our universe, the total amount of spinning in any isolated system always stays the same. So over time, through collisions and crashes, the cloud loses its loft and flattens into a spinning, roughly two dimensional, disk shape, like a solar system or spiral galaxy.
---

claim: 随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘。
question_src: 为什么太阳能系统看起来主要是“平坦”？
all_claims: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定[1]。
当云中的尘埃和气体不断相互碰撞时，粒子虽可向任意方向移动，但垂直于旋转平面的上行与下行运动相互抵消，使系统逐渐失去高度[1]。
随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘[2]。
这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。

这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Is The Solar System Flat? (www.scienceabc.com)
Content: The flatness of our solar system can be ascribed to the law of conservation of total angular momentum. Due to this, whenever particles collide, they may move in any direction, but all the up and down motion cancels out, always following the rule that the total spin in that plane must be constant.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why is the Solar System flat? – How It Works (www.howitworksdaily.com)
Content: This is due to a rule known as the conservation of angular momentum – the total amount of spinning in any isolated system, such as the Solar System, will always remain constant. This allowed the cloud to flatten over time, losing its height and becoming the roughly two-dimensional disc we see today.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Discover how the solar system, which started as a shapeless spherical blob ended up being flat (www.britannica.com)
Content: As the particles bump into each other, all the up and down motion tends to cancel out, it's energy lost in crashing and clumping. Yet, the whole mass must continue spinning, inexorably, because in our universe, the total amount of spinning in any isolated system always stays the same. So over time, through collisions and crashes, the cloud loses its loft and flattens into a spinning, roughly two dimensional, disk shape, like a solar system or spiral galaxy.
---

claim: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机。
question_src: 为什么大多数汽车在6,250-6,500 rpm范围内都红线：永远不会降低，很少更高？
all_claims: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机[1]。
现代内燃机的技术与材料使其极限通常落在4,000-7,000 rpm 区间[3]，而6,000 rpm 上下既能充分利用气门机构、活塞平均速度与润滑系统的安全裕度，又不必采用赛车级轻量活瓣、钛连杆等昂贵部件。
另一方面，普通道路驾驶的功率需求在2,000-3,000 rpm 即可满足[2]，因此继续提高红线对用户体验的收益有限，却会带来更高油耗、排放与噪声，同时需要更短的变速比，牺牲巡航经济性。
综合耐久、成本、法规与实用性能，6,250-6,500 rpm 成为绝大多数乘用车最经济也最安全的红线区间。
claims_retained: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Redlining a Car: 3 Common Automotive Myths Debunked (knowhow.napaonline.com)
Content: The redline on your car’s tachometer is there to indicate the maximum safe rotational speed of the motor, measured in revolutions per minute. The key word here is safe. This is the limit that the manufacturer has tested and found to be perfectly fine in regular operation. Running an engine up to that point will in no way damage it.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Revolutions per minute (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: Modern automobile engines are typically operated around 2,000–3,000 rpm (33–50 Hz) when cruising, with a minimum (idle) speed around 750–900 rpm (12.5–15 Hz), and an upper limit anywhere from 4500 to 10,000 rpm (75–166 Hz) for a road car, or nearly (sometimes over) 20,000 rpm for racing engines such as those in Formula 1 cars (during the 2006 season, with the 2.4 L N/A V8 engine configuration; currently limited to 15,000 rpm, with the 1.6 L V6 turbo-hybrid engine configuration).
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Measurements at 36,000 RPM (www.fst.com)
Content: While the internal combustion engines in cars today reach a maximum rotational speed between 4,000 and 7,000 rpm, depending on the combustion process, the figure for electric motors is significantly higher. Today electric motors for series production vehicles reach a maximum rotational speed of more than 20,000 rpm.
---

claim: 相机镜头会把这束光进一步聚焦，使光强超过CMOS/CCD可承受的最大曝光限度，没有预留安全裕度。
question_src: 为什么Lazor或明亮的光线禁用数码相机？
all_claims: 激光输出高度集中的光束，能量密度远高于普通光[3]。
相机镜头会把这束光进一步聚焦，使光强超过CMOS/CCD可承受的最大曝光限度，没有预留安全裕度[2]。
过量能量会加热感光层，烧毁像素，形成死点或大片黑区，严重时整块传感器报废[3]。
即便未被烧毁，极亮光也会使像素瞬间饱和，画面全白，令相机暂时“失明”[1]。
在夜间，攻击者用红外激光、大功率LED或反光板把强红外光直接射入启用夜视的摄像机，可利用其对红外异常敏感的特性彻底挡住监控画面[1]。

Content: Lasers emit concentrated beams of light, which can heat up sensitive surfaces (like the eye's retina) and cause damage. Camera sensors are, in general, more susceptible to damage than the human eye.


For large scale shows such as televised concerts, laser show producers work with clients to avoid TV camera locations and video projectors (ILDA Members, see this page for details; login required). However, it is not possible for laser show producers to be responsible for all cameras, smartphones and camcorders which might be used at a show.


Tips for audience members with cameras when lasers are in use




If you attend a laser show as an audience member, you should take reasonable precautions not to let a laser beam DIRECTLY enter your camera lens.


* You can photograph the beams in midair, or doing graphics on a screen. If you can't see the laser source (projector output aperture or bounce mirror) in your viewfinder, this means you're not getting the full beam power into your lens. Indirect viewing like this should not cause damage.




* Avoid beams which are coming straight into your lens (or bounced off a mirror or other reflective surface and then into your lens). The damage potential is much greater when the entire beam power enters the camera lens.


Degree of camera damage




The degree of damage can vary widely.


* We have seen cases of minor damage, such as small areas of a few pixels which no longer work. The pixels are not noticeable unless in an area of uniform color such as a blue sky.

Content: The sun shines, the wind blows — until it doesn’t. On the flip side, sometimes it’s too sunny out, or too windy. question_src: 开尔文量表如何可能进行负温度？
all_claims: 在热力学中温度定义为 T = (∂S/∂E)⁻¹，当能量增加反而使熵减少时 ∂S/∂E 为负，T 就成为负值；这只有在能级数目有限、存在能量上限的系统里才可能发生[1]。
通过外部“抽运”制造占据反转，使高能级原子的数目多于低能级，把这种异常分布代入玻尔兹曼公式即可算出负温度[2]。
负开尔文并不“更冷”，相反它比任何正温度都“更热”，若与普通物体相接触会把热量传给后者[1]。
实验上，科研人员在光学晶格中突然把“山谷”变为“山丘”，令原子整体跃迁到能带上缘，从而制备出负温度的超冷气体，验证了这一概念[3]。
因此，开尔文量表出现负温度并非违背绝对零度定义，而是源于特定有限能级系统中的熵-能量关系反转。
claims_retained: 通过外部“抽运”制造占据反转，使高能级原子的数目多于低能级，把这种异常分布代入玻尔兹曼公式即可算出负温度[2]。

question_src: 开尔文量表如何可能进行负温度？
all_claims: 在热力学中温度定义为 T = (∂S/∂E)⁻¹，当能量增加反而使熵减少时 ∂S/∂E 为负，T 就成为负值；这只有在能级数目有限、存在能量上限的系统里才可能发生[1]。
通过外部“抽运”制造占据反转，使高能级原子的数目多于低能级，把这种异常分布代入玻尔兹曼公式即可算出负温度[2]。
负开尔文并不“更冷”，相反它比任何正温度都“更热”，若与普通物体相接触会把热量传给后者[1]。
实验上，科研人员在光学晶格中突然把“山谷”变为“山丘”，令原子整体跃迁到能带上缘，从而制备出负温度的超冷气体，验证了这一概念[3]。
因此，开尔文量表出现负温度并非违背绝对零度定义，而是源于特定有限能级系统中的熵-能量关系反转。

claim: 流感病毒之所以不断突变，首先是因为在复制过程中会出现小规模基因改变，即“抗原漂移”，这些突变可导致其表面蛋白血凝素（HA）和神经氨酸酶（NA）发生变化[1]；随着病毒持续复制，这些微小改变会逐渐累积，最终形成在抗原性质上有所差异的新病毒株。
question_src: 流感病毒为什么突变？
all_claims: 流感病毒之所以不断突变，首先是因为在复制过程中会出现小规模基因改变，即“抗原漂移”，这些突变可导致其表面蛋白血凝素（HA）和神经氨酸酶（NA）发生变化[1]；随着病毒持续复制，这些微小改变会逐渐累积，最终形成在抗原性质上有所差异的新病毒株[3]。
其次，流感 A 病毒还可能经历一次性的大幅度基因重排或“抗原转移”，从而突然产生全新的 HA 和/或 NA 蛋白，使病毒特性发生质变[4]。
这种重大突变的一种情形是动物中的流感病毒获得感染人类的能力，与人类或其他动物病毒交换基因片段后产生新型病毒[5]。
从分子机制看，病毒突变与其复制并复制自身遗传物质的方式紧密相关，这一过程本身易于出错，因此不断孕育新的变体[6]。

claim: 即使感冒等炎症让下鼻甲（下涡轮增压）黏膜总体肿胀，鼻腔仍会接受自主神经系统驱动的“鼻周期”管理：血流被周期性地重新分配，使一个鼻孔血管扩张、充血，约 3–6 小时后再把血液抽回并转向另一侧；当血液撤离时，原先肿胀的黏膜迅速瘪下，腾出更多空气通道，因此“堵”侧就感觉突然畅通，而新充血的一侧则变得相对拥塞。
question_src: 如果鼻子被炎症引起，那么阻塞开关侧如何自由？
all_claims: 即使感冒等炎症让下鼻甲（下涡轮增压）黏膜总体肿胀，鼻腔仍会接受自主神经系统驱动的“鼻周期”管理：血流被周期性地重新分配，使一个鼻孔血管扩张、充血，约 3–6 小时后再把血液抽回并转向另一侧[1]；当血液撤离时，原先肿胀的黏膜迅速瘪下，腾出更多空气通道，因此“堵”侧就感觉突然畅通，而新充血的一侧则变得相对拥塞。
炎症会放大每侧的肿胀程度，但不会停止这一血流开关，所以人们在生病期间依然会体验到两侧交替的“忽堵忽通”。
此外，因下鼻甲负责加湿与加温空气，它们在炎症时更易因工作量大而肿胀，但随着血流重新分配、炎性反应逐步减轻，阻塞侧也会随之自由[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Here's The Frustrating Reason Only One Side of Your Nose Gets Blocked at a Time (www.sciencealert.com)
Content: During the day, the sides switch and the other nostril goes into 'work mode', but why?


This process is automated by the aptly named autonomic nervous system, which is the same system that controls many things your body does all by itself such as digestion and heart rate.


For your nose, this system controls your 'nasal cycle', so that each nostril operates effectively.


The nasal cycle happens, according to the US National Library of Medicine, several times during the day, and is only brought to your attention if your nose is clogged up more than usual.


In order to open one side of your nose and close the other, your body inflates tissue with blood in the same way that a man gets an erection, except, you know, in your nose.


"Increased blood flow causes congestion in one nostril for about 3 to 6 hours before switching to the other side. There is also increased congestion when one is lying down, which can be especially noticeable when the head is turned to one side," Jennifer Shu reports for CNN.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Science Behind Why Only One Nostril Clogs When You’re Sick (www.menshealth.com)
Content: Structures in both sides of your nose called inferior turbinates are responsible for warming and humidifying air before it reaches your lungs, says Dr. Roditi. This protects your lungs by reducing dryness and irritation.


That process is a lot of work. So your nose funnels its resources more to one side than the other to make the process more efficient.
---
