claim: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点。
question_src: 将异物应用于棒球（例如Pine Tar，Vaseline，Crisco）如何使投手比击球手具有竞争优势？为什么值得冒险？
all_claims: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点[1]。
而把松焦油等黏性物质抹在手指或球缝上，则能增强抓地力，投手可施加更高后旋，令直球停空更久、曲球折弯更大，从而扩大好球区边缘的可利用空间[1]。
松焦油或防晒霜还会让断球“咬”得更紧，使滑球、曲线球晃动幅度扩大[2]。
更牢的握球同样降低失控球率，一些击球手甚至支持这种做法，因为球不易失投砸人[3]。
较少的保送与更诡异的球路可转化为更多出局，每年可能为投手节省几个自责分，而违规曝光代价通常只是短期停赛或罚款，因此许多人认为回报远超风险。
claims_retained: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点[1]。

If Rogers had wet, slippery mud or clay on his hand, he might have been moistening up his pitches.

One Cardinals player suspected that Rogers had a sticky substance called pine tar on his hand. What advantage would sticky fingers provide? If a pitcher makes the ball sticky—or if he makes his fingers sticky—he might be able to get a tighter grip and throw the ball with more spin. A fastball with more backspin would stay up longer; a curveball with more spin would have a larger break.

而把松焦油等黏性物质抹在手指或球缝上，则能增强抓地力，投手可施加更高后旋，令直球停空更久、曲球折弯更大，从而扩大好球区边缘的可利用空间[1]。
松焦油或防晒霜还会让断球“咬”得更紧，使滑球、曲线球晃动幅度扩大[2]。
更牢的握球同样降低失控球率，一些击球手甚至支持这种做法，因为球不易失投砸人[3]。
较少的保送与更诡异的球路可转化为更多出局，每年可能为投手节省几个自责分，而违规曝光代价通常只是短期停赛或罚款，因此许多人认为回报远超风险。
claims_retained: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点[1]。
而把松焦油等黏性物质抹在手指或球缝上，则能增强抓地力，投手可施加更高后旋，令直球停空更久、曲球折弯更大，从而扩大好球区边缘的可利用空间[1]。
松焦油或防晒霜还会让断球“咬”得更紧，使滑球、曲线球晃动幅度扩大[2]。
更牢的握球同样降低失控球率，一些击球手甚至支持这种做法，因为球不易失投砸人[3]。

Title: The physics of baseball's most popular illegal pitches. (slate.com)
Content: Cheaters who don’t scuff can throw the “spitter” instead. By lubricating the ball—with saliva, Vaseline, hair grease, or something else—the pitcher can throw a pitch that slides off his fingers without generating too much backspin. A greased-up pitch behaves kind of like a split-fingered fastball—it drops to the ground faster than a typical pitch. If Rogers had wet, slippery mud or clay on his hand, he might have been moistening up his pitches.

One Cardinals player suspected that Rogers had a sticky substance called pine tar on his hand. What advantage would sticky fingers provide? If a pitcher makes the ball sticky—or if he makes his fingers sticky—he might be able to get a tighter grip and throw the ball with more spin. A fastball with more backspin would stay up longer; a curveball with more spin would have a larger break.

question_src: 四大会做什么？
all_claims: “四大”指德勤、普华永道、毕马威和安永，是全球规模最大的专业服务网络[1]。
它们为标准普尔500指数绝大多数公司审核财报[2]，核心业务是审计，并可提供交易咨询，如业务建模、并购及估值等服务，帮助企业评估和推动各类交易[1]。
此外，四大还提供广泛的咨询、税务、风险咨询与精算服务，满足企业治理与合规需要[1]；亦能提供估值、市场研究、保证及法律咨询等专业支持[2]。
当遇到潜在法律纠纷时，四大可进行法医式审核，对公司记录进行深入检查以备法院使用[1]。

Title: Reforming the Big Four (www.economist.com)
Content: Instead regulators should sharpen tools that are already available in Europe. They could lower the cap on non-audit fees charged to an audit client from today’s generous level of 70% of the audit fee. Under rules introduced in 2016, British companies with the same auditor for ten years must re-tender; they are forced to rotate after 20. Such rules look draconian to American eyes, where the average auditor tenure for the first 21 companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average to have made disclosures this year is a cosy 66 years. New research finds that auditors are most likely to find misstatements early in their tenure; by the tenth year, the benefits of a fresh pair of eyes are lost. Academics also find that the Big Four’s fees rise with tenure. Even Britain’s 20-year limit is too long.


Auditors in many countries are already required to add flesh to the bare bones of the audit opinion. That is to be encouraged. Transparency over the main points of contention with management, and the size of revisions made to the accounts as a result of scrutiny, would cast light on auditors’ successes, not just their failures. And that in turn would help investors to assess auditors’ performance.

question_src: 当您感到肠胃疼痛（例如胃痉挛？）时，为什么它会倾向于弯曲到球中并保持脚的温暖，为什么以及如何缓解疼痛？
all_claims: 当腹部平滑肌不受意志控制地强烈收缩引发胃痉挛时，人会本能地蜷成胎儿姿势；此时腹壁放松、背部支撑增强，肠管受到的牵拉与压迫随之减少，膝盖贴近胸部还可为缺乏骨骼保护的腹部提供“护甲”，令大脑获得温暖与安全的讯号，降低因压力激活的交感神经反应，从而缓解疼痛[1]。
把脚收拢和双臂环抱也能减少散热、微升体温，进一步促进副交感神经活动，抑制平滑肌痉挛与炎症。
由于胃肠道属于无法由意志直接调控的平滑肌，人们在胃流感或食物中毒时无法主动减慢其过快蠕动[2]，因此只能借助上述姿势，并配合热敷腹部、少量多次补水、电解质、避免油腻刺激等方法，促使神经系统转入“休息与消化”模式，间接减弱痉挛；若剧痛持续或伴高热、呕血，应及时就医。
claims_retained: 由于胃肠道属于无法由意志直接调控的平滑肌，人们在胃流感或食物中毒时无法主动减慢其过快蠕动[2]，因此只能借助上述姿势，并配合热敷腹部、少量多次补水、电解质、避免油腻刺激等方法，促使神经系统转入“休息与消化”模式，间接减弱痉挛；若剧痛持续或伴高热、呕血，应及时就医。

Title: Why do We go into Fetal Position During Stomach Ache? (www.hngn.com)
Content: Health experts say that foetal position is a "natural defensive" position that alleviates the stomach ache. And it is all due to a person's mind and body.


Dr Bob Adams, family practice and sports medicine specialist, said that people get a sense of protection while being in the fetal position. "When we have bad news, pain, or something's really stressful, we hunch up. It probably goes back to when we were in the uterus." This makes people feel warm and safe.

Document ID: 2
Title: Why do We go into Fetal Position During Stomach Ache? (www.hngn.com)
Content: However, physiological explanation to curling up into the fetus posture might be difficult to explain unless the root cause of the pain in known. But, Dr Adams explained on Outside Online  that there are possible circumstances. For example, bowels speed up while a person is down with stomach flu or food poisoning. This is simply because body wants to flush out the toxin from the system, explained Dr Adams.


Human body is made up of three types of muscle: smooth, cardiac, and skeletal. And gastrointestinal tract is smooth muscle, which regulates its own movement. "You can't directly control your smooth muscles," Dr Adams said. "You can't actively slow down or speed up (smooth muscle contractions) by doing something."

claim: 光不是被某种“推力”推动的粒子流，而是一对相互交替的电场与磁场组成的电磁波：当带电粒子在光源处振动时，它产生的电振动会自动诱导垂直的磁振动，这对振荡从源头不断向外扩散，无需任何物质介质；光因此能够在真空传播 。
question_src: 我们都知道光线每秒行驶186,282英里。但是它如何旅行。是什么为这种速度提供了推力？为什么它会旅行而不是坐在那里呢？
all_claims: 光不是被某种“推力”推动的粒子流，而是一对相互交替的电场与磁场组成的电磁波：当带电粒子在光源处振动时，它产生的电振动会自动诱导垂直的磁振动，这对振荡从源头不断向外扩散，无需任何物质介质；光因此能够在真空传播 [1]。
在真空中，这种电磁波总以每秒约186,282英里（约3×10⁸ m/s）的固定速度传播，无论场强变化得多快或多慢，速度都保持不变 [2]。
这一速度由真空本身的电、磁性质决定，而非由外力驱动，因此“推进”这个概念并不适用；光之所以持续前进，是因为电场变化必然产生磁场变化，磁场变化又必然产生电场变化，它们彼此“自我维持”成连续的波动。
没有介质的阻尼，波不会衰减，因而能从遥远恒星穿行数十亿光年仍抵达地球 [3]。
claims_retained: 光不是被某种“推力”推动的粒子流，而是一对相互交替的电场与磁场组成的电磁波：当带电粒子在光源处振动时，它产生的电振动会自动诱导垂直的磁振动，这对振荡从源头不断向外扩散，无需任何物质介质；光因此能够在真空传播 [1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How Does Light Travel? (sciencing.com)
Content: In the mid 1800s, Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell established that light is a form of electromagnetic energy that travels in waves. The question of how it manages to do so in the absence of a medium is explained by the nature of electromagnetic vibrations. When a charged particle vibrates, it produces an electrical vibration that automatically induces a magnetic one -- physicists often visualize these vibrations occurring in perpendicular planes. The paired oscillations propagate outward from the source; no medium, except for the electromagnetic field that permeates the universe, is required to conduct them.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Content: When I say "waves of electric and magnetic fields," I'm talking about something similar to the waves in the rope. Similar to wiggling the end of the rope, we can change the electric or magnetic field at one point, and that disturbance travels away from us. (One way to change the magnetic field at a point is to hold a magnet there, then wiggle it back and forth.) Unlike the wave in the rope, these waves actually travel away from us in all directions. It turns out that in a vacuum, for example in outer space, these waves travel at exactly the speed of light! It doesn't matter how rapidly the fields wiggle back and forth, they will always travel at the same speed. (In air, the waves go ever so slightly slower than in vacuum, and in glass, they can go only about two-thirds as fast as they would in vacuum, but this is not important right now. From now on, when I talk about the speed of light, I mean the speed of light in a vacuum, and I'm talking about waves traveling in a vacuum.) The conclusion that physicists have drawn from this result is that light consists of waves of electric and magnetic fields. This is a fascinating result: that we learn something about light by studying magnets and electrical currents.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Q & A: Does light travel forever? | Department of Physics (van.physics.illinois.edu)
Content: In contrast, light waves can travel through a vacuum, and do not require a medium. In empty space, the wave does not dissipate (grow smaller) no matter how far it travels, because the wave is not interacting with anything else. This is why light from distant stars can travel through space for billions of light-years and still reach us on earth. However, light can also travel within some materials, like glass and water. In this case, some light is absorbed and lost as heat, just like sound. So, underwater, or in our atmosphere, light will only travel some finite range (which is different depending on the properties of the material it travels through).
---

all_claims: 光不是被某种“推力”推动的粒子流，而是一对相互交替的电场与磁场组成的电磁波：当带电粒子在光源处振动时，它产生的电振动会自动诱导垂直的磁振动，这对振荡从源头不断向外扩散，无需任何物质介质；光因此能够在真空传播 [1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How Does Light Travel? (sciencing.com)
Content: In the mid 1800s, Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell established that light is a form of electromagnetic energy that travels in waves. The question of how it manages to do so in the absence of a medium is explained by the nature of electromagnetic vibrations. When a charged particle vibrates, it produces an electrical vibration that automatically induces a magnetic one -- physicists often visualize these vibrations occurring in perpendicular planes. The paired oscillations propagate outward from the source; no medium, except for the electromagnetic field that permeates the universe, is required to conduct them.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Content: When I say "waves of electric and magnetic fields," I'm talking about something similar to the waves in the rope. Similar to wiggling the end of the rope, we can change the electric or magnetic field at one point, and that disturbance travels away from us. (One way to change the magnetic field at a point is to hold a magnet there, then wiggle it back and forth.) Unlike the wave in the rope, these waves actually travel away from us in all directions. It turns out that in a vacuum, for example in outer space, these waves travel at exactly the speed of light! It doesn't matter how rapidly the fields wiggle back and forth, they will always travel at the same speed. (In air, the waves go ever so slightly slower than in vacuum, and in glass, they can go only about two-thirds as fast as they would in vacuum, but this is not important right now. From now on, when I talk about the speed of light, I mean the speed of light in a vacuum, and I'm talking about waves traveling in a vacuum.) The conclusion that physicists have drawn from this result is that light consists of waves of electric and magnetic fields. This is a fascinating result: that we learn something about light by studying magnets and electrical currents.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Q & A: Does light travel forever? | Department of Physics (van.physics.illinois.edu)
Content: In contrast, light waves can travel through a vacuum, and do not require a medium. In empty space, the wave does not dissipate (grow smaller) no matter how far it travels, because the wave is not interacting with anything else. So, underwater, or in our atmosphere, light will only travel some finite range (which is different depending on the properties of the material it travels through).

question_src: 动物如何处理脚上的刺/荆棘/碎片等？
all_claims: 当狗等哺乳动物踩到刺或木屑时，常见的处理是立即清创并拔除：兽医建议先以温暖肥皂水冲洗伤口、再用消毒镊子夹出刺片，随后再次冲洗以降低感染风险[3]。
若异物留在体内且无法及时取出，机体往往无法完全吸收或分解它，免疫系统会在刺片周围形成炎性组织并随着皮肤更新逐渐把异物向外顶出，最终将其排出体表[4]。
某些动物还通过“预防”减少足部受伤；例如刺龙虾壳上向前排列的坚硬棘刺在移动时可挡开尖锐物或掠食者，降低异物刺入脚部的概率[2]。
综上，动物应对脚上刺/荆棘/碎片的方式大致分为：主动拔除、免疫排异及结构性防护三种机制。

claim: Microsoft Internet Explorer 存在编号为 CVE-2018-0954 的远程代码执行漏洞，其根本原因是脚本引擎在处理内存中对象时可能发生损坏，从而允许注入并执行任意代码 。
question_src: MS Internet Explorer脆弱性以及为什么Chrome和Firefox不会受到影响？
all_claims: Microsoft Internet Explorer 存在编号为 CVE-2018-0954 的远程代码执行漏洞，其根本原因是脚本引擎在处理内存中对象时可能发生损坏，从而允许注入并执行任意代码 [1]。
攻击者只需诱导受害者访问专门制作的网页，即可在计算机上安装程序、查看、修改或删除数据，甚至完全接管系统 [4]。
这一高风险与 IE 的架构密切相关：它依赖深度集成于 Windows 的 Trident 引擎和 ActiveX 技术，浏览器进程一旦失守，恶意代码即可继承较高系统权限 [2]。
相较之下，Chrome 与 Firefox 采用多进程“沙箱”模型，将网页渲染、脚本执行等高危操作隔离在受限进程中，即使发生内存破坏也难以逃离沙箱、影响整机 [3]。
因此，同样的攻击手法在 Chrome 或 Firefox 上通常只能导致受限进程崩溃，而无法取得系统控制权，使其不受上述 IE 脆弱性的影响。
claims_retained: Microsoft Internet Explorer 存在编号为 CVE-2018-0954 的远程代码执行漏洞，其根本原因是脚本引擎在处理内存中对象时可能发生损坏，从而允许注入并执行任意代码 [1]。

In fact, both Chrome and Firefox have rigorous security in place. Both include a thing called “sandboxing” which separates the processes of the browser so something like a harmful website doesn’t infect other parts of your laptop or other device.

相较之下，Chrome 与 Firefox 采用多进程“沙箱”模型，将网页渲染、脚本执行等高危操作隔离在受限进程中，即使发生内存破坏也难以逃离沙箱、影响整机 [3]。
因此，同样的攻击手法在 Chrome 或 Firefox 上通常只能导致受限进程崩溃，而无法取得系统控制权，使其不受上述 IE 脆弱性的影响。

热量停止流动，机械、电气等能量形式也随之达到平衡，使得通过任何方式提取功都变得不可能[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Heat death of the universe (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The heat death of the universe (also known as the Big Chill or Big Freeze)[1] is a theory on the ultimate fate of the universe, which suggests the universe would evolve to a state of no thermodynamic free energy and would therefore be unable to sustain processes that increase entropy. Heat death does not imply any particular absolute temperature; it only requires that temperature differences or other processes may no longer be exploited to perform work. In the language of physics, this is when the universe reaches thermodynamic equilibrium
---
Document ID: 2
Title: What exactly is the heat death of the universe and where can I find out more? (www.physlink.com)
Content: The 'heat-death' of the universe is when the universe has reached a state of maximum entropy. This happens when all available energy (such as from a hot source) has moved to places of less energy (such as a colder source). Once this has happened, no more work can be extracted from the universe.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What exactly is the heat death of the universe and where can I find out more? (www.physlink.com)
Content: Since heat ceases to flow, no more work can be acquired from heat transfer. This same kind of equilibrium state will also happen with all other forms of energy (mechanical, electrical, etc.). Since no more work can be extracted from the universe at that point, it is effectively dead, especially for the purposes of humankind.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: What is Heat Death? | Space Facts – Astronomy, the Solar System & Outer Space | All About Space Magazine (www.spaceanswers.com)
Content: Entropy, which is the number of ways in which a system can be arranged should never decrease, evolving to a state of maximum disorder (or thermodynamic equilibrium). When this happens, all energy will be evenly distributed throughout the cosmos, leaving no room for any reusable energy or heat to burst into existence.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: What Will Happen to Earth When the Sun Dies? (www.livescience.com)
Content: On the bright side, the sun's luminosity is increasing by a factor of about 10 percent every billion years. The habitable zone, where liquid water can exist on a planet's surface, right now is between about 0.95 and 1.37 times the radius of the Earth's orbit (otherwise known as astronomical units, or AU). That zone will continue to move outward. By the time the sun gets ready to become a red giant, Mars will have been inside the zone for quite some time.
---

结果是能量在整个宇宙中极度均匀分布，没有可重复利用的能量或“热裂缝”，宇宙就像被彻底“冷冻”一般，进入一种对人类而言形同死亡的静态[4]。

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Heat death of the universe (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The heat death of the universe (also known as the Big Chill or Big Freeze)[1] is a theory on the ultimate fate of the universe, which suggests the universe would evolve to a state of no thermodynamic free energy and would therefore be unable to sustain processes that increase entropy. Heat death does not imply any particular absolute temperature; it only requires that temperature differences or other processes may no longer be exploited to perform work. In the language of physics, this is when the universe reaches thermodynamic equilibrium
---
Document ID: 2
Title: What exactly is the heat death of the universe and where can I find out more? (www.physlink.com)
Content: The 'heat-death' of the universe is when the universe has reached a state of maximum entropy. This happens when all available energy (such as from a hot source) has moved to places of less energy (such as a colder source). Once this has happened, no more work can be extracted from the universe.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What exactly is the heat death of the universe and where can I find out more? (www.physlink.com)
Content: Since heat ceases to flow, no more work can be acquired from heat transfer. This same kind of equilibrium state will also happen with all other forms of energy (mechanical, electrical, etc.). Since no more work can be extracted from the universe at that point, it is effectively dead, especially for the purposes of humankind.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: What is Heat Death? | Space Facts – Astronomy, the Solar System & Outer Space | All About Space Magazine (www.spaceanswers.com)
Content: Entropy, which is the number of ways in which a system can be arranged should never decrease, evolving to a state of maximum disorder (or thermodynamic equilibrium). When this happens, all energy will be evenly distributed throughout the cosmos, leaving no room for any reusable energy or heat to burst into existence.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: What Will Happen to Earth When the Sun Dies? (www.livescience.com)
Content: On the bright side, the sun's luminosity is increasing by a factor of about 10 percent every billion years. The habitable zone, where liquid water can exist on a planet's surface, right now is between about 0.95 and 1.37 times the radius of the Earth's orbit (otherwise known as astronomical units, or AU). That zone will continue to move outward. By the time the sun gets ready to become a red giant, Mars will have been inside the zone for quite some time.
---

question_src: 电话如何工作？
all_claims: 当你说话时，手机内的微型麦克风把声波振动转换成对应的电信号[1]；这些信号被微芯片数字化成数字串并封装进无线电波，经天线发射[1]。
无线电波以接近光速（约30 万公里/秒）飞向最近的基站[1]。
运营商核心网随后对信号进行路由，将其送往对方手机所在区域的基站[2]；在长距离传输中，信号通常沿光纤，也可能通过卫星或微波塔跨越海陆[3]。
到达目标基站后，信号再以无线形式发射至对方手机，该手机把数字数据还原为电信号，并由扬声器重新转换成声音，让对方听见[4]。
整个过程中，模拟声波→电信号→数字信息→无线电波→数字信息→电信号→声音的多次转换，确保了语音清晰、实时地在全球范围传递。

Title: How do cellphones work? (www.explainthatstuff.com)
Content: When you speak into a cellphone, a tiny microphone in the handset converts the up-and-down sounds of your voice into a corresponding up-and-down pattern of electrical signals. A microchip inside the phone turns these signals into strings of numbers. The numbers are packed up into a radio wave and beamed out from the phone's antenna (in some countries, the antenna is called an aerial). The radio wave races through the air at the speed of light until it reaches the nearest cellphone mast.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How do cellphones work? (www.explainthatstuff.com)
Content: Calls made from a cellphone to another cellphone on the same network travel to their destination by being routed to the base station nearest to the destination phone, and finally to that phone itself.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How Telephones Work (electronics.howstuffworks.com)
Content: Your voice normally travels over a fiber-optic line to the office of the receiving party, but it may also be transmitted by satellite or by microwave towers.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How Do Cell Phones Work? – Pong Pulse (pongcase.com)
Content: When you chat with your friend on your cell phone, your phone converts your voice into an electrical signal, which is then transmitted via radio waves to the nearest cell tower. The network of cell towers then relays the radio wave to your friend’s cell phone, which converts it to an electrical signal and then back to sound again
---

question_src: 燃料机如何知道我的水箱何时满？
all_claims: 加油枪能“知道”油箱已满，靠的是喷嘴内一根细小的感应管与阀门组成的压力-真空系统[1]。
当汽油注入时，它不断把油箱中的空气挤进这根管道并排出，产生稳定的气流压力，从而让阀门保持开启[2]。
随着油位上升到封住管道口，空气流被汽油阻断，压力骤然消失并在管内形成小型吸力（文丘里效应），触发阀门跳至关闭位置，立即停止供油[2]。
因此，加油枪通过监测这股空气压力与真空变化，而非直接测量油面，就能在油箱加满的瞬间自动断油，防止溢出[2]。

因此，加油枪通过监测这股空气压力与真空变化，而非直接测量油面，就能在油箱加满的瞬间自动断油，防止溢出[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How Do Gas Pumps “Know” When Your Car’s Tank Is Full? (www.rd.com)
Content: Well, it has to do with the way the gas pump works. When you fill your tank with gas, you’re replacing the air that’s in there. “The more gas goes in, the more air must come out,” explains Jake McKenzie, Content Manager at Auto Accessories Garage. “It comes out through a small pipe located just inside the gas nozzle.”
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How Do Gas Pumps “Know” When Your Car’s Tank Is Full? (www.rd.com)
Content: And pressure has built up in the tank; that pressure is released as the air escapes. McKenzie compares it to holding your thumb over a garden hose: “Blocking part of the hose [increases] the pressure of the water inside, [causing] the water leaving to spray out at an even greater velocity.” When you start to pump gas, the pipe, which has been “blocked” like the hose, releases the air quickly. “This expelled air brings with it a pressure that’s strong enough to hold the valve in the open position,” McKenzie says.


So that’s what happens while you’re filling up your tank. And once it’s full of gas, gasoline, not air, now reaches the pipe inside the nozzle, which evens out the pressure. As McKenzie explains, this creates “a small suctioning force (known as the Venturi effect) that switches the valve to the off position.”
---

question_src: 石油猜测。到底是什么，为什么这么糟糕？
all_claims: 石油猜测是指投资者依据政治或经济事件的预期，在期货等市场频繁买卖石油资产以博取差价[1]；这类投机者唯一动机是从油价变动中赚钱，并不真正需要实体石油[2]。
当他们预估需求上升时提前大量买入，会抬高期货乃至现货价格，把更高成本传递给炼厂和消费者[1]。
为捕捉细小波动，这些交易往往使用衍生品和高杠杆，使油价对新闻、利率、冲突等极度敏感，波动剧烈，令企业难以制定预算，增加宏观经济不确定性。
价格过度受情绪驱动而偏离供需基本面，还可能误导产油国投资决策和消费者行为，形成资源错配。
因推高价格、加剧波动、脱实向虚等副作用，石油猜测常被视为“糟糕”的市场现象。

claim: 在保险实践中，“代位求偿”（subrogation）指保险人向被保险人理赔后，继承其对造成损失的第三方行使追偿权，以收回赔款并防止责任方逃避责任；而“放弃代位求偿”（waiver of subrogation）则是在保单或相关合同中约定，保险公司自愿放弃上述追偿权。
question_src: 保险中的子摄取和豁免
all_claims: 在保险实践中，“代位求偿”（subrogation）指保险人向被保险人理赔后，继承其对造成损失的第三方行使追偿权，以收回赔款并防止责任方逃避责任；而“放弃代位求偿”（waiver of subrogation）则是在保单或相关合同中约定，保险公司自愿放弃上述追偿权[1]。
这样做的直接好处是避免冗长的诉讼及其费用，并减少房东与租户、承包方之间等合同当事人的冲突[2]。
此类条款最常见于商业综合责任、建筑或租赁合同的保险中，被视为风险由一方转移至另一方的重要机制[3]。
然而，一旦放弃追偿，保险人失去通过诉讼收回损失的途径，可能以提高保费或限制承保范围来弥补风险；因此企业或个人在同意放弃代位求偿之前，应权衡保费变化、合同要求及自身潜在责任，确保整体风险处于可控水平。
claims_retained: 在保险实践中，“代位求偿”（subrogation）指保险人向被保险人理赔后，继承其对造成损失的第三方行使追偿权，以收回赔款并防止责任方逃避责任；而“放弃代位求偿”（waiver of subrogation）则是在保单或相关合同中约定，保险公司自愿放弃上述追偿权[1]。
这样做的直接好处是避免冗长的诉讼及其费用，并减少房东与租户、承包方之间等合同当事人的冲突[2]。
此类条款最常见于商业综合责任、建筑或租赁合同的保险中，被视为风险由一方转移至另一方的重要机制[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: What Is A Waiver Of Subrogation? (2021) (generalliabilityinsure.com)
Content: A waiver of subrogation clause is an policy endorsement where the insurance carrier waives its right to recover the money they paid on a claim from a negligent third party.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: What a Waiver of Subrogation Provides for Clients (www.investopedia.com)
Content: One of the most common benefits of a waiver of subrogation is the avoidance of lengthy litigation and negotiation, as well as the costs to pursue them. These provisions can also prevent conflict between parties to a contract, such as between a landlord and tenant. They also prevent certain parties from being held responsible for losses for which they did not cause.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Waiver of subrogation explained (www.thimble.com)

question_src: 保险中的子摄取和豁免
all_claims: 在保险实践中，“代位求偿”（subrogation）指保险人向被保险人理赔后，继承其对造成损失的第三方行使追偿权，以收回赔款并防止责任方逃避责任；而“放弃代位求偿”（waiver of subrogation）则是在保单或相关合同中约定，保险公司自愿放弃上述追偿权[1]。
这样做的直接好处是避免冗长的诉讼及其费用，并减少房东与租户、承包方之间等合同当事人的冲突[2]。
此类条款最常见于商业综合责任、建筑或租赁合同的保险中，被视为风险由一方转移至另一方的重要机制[3]。
然而，一旦放弃追偿，保险人失去通过诉讼收回损失的途径，可能以提高保费或限制承保范围来弥补风险；因此企业或个人在同意放弃代位求偿之前，应权衡保费变化、合同要求及自身潜在责任，确保整体风险处于可控水平。

这样做的直接好处是避免冗长的诉讼及其费用，并减少房东与租户、承包方之间等合同当事人的冲突[2]。

---

Content: One of the most common benefits of a waiver of subrogation is the avoidance of lengthy litigation and negotiation, as well as the costs to pursue them. These provisions can also prevent conflict between parties to a contract, such as between a landlord and tenant. They also prevent certain parties from being held responsible for losses for which they did not cause.

Content: If you experience light sensitivity as a symptom of migraine, consider limiting your exposure to computer screens and other sources of bright light while you recover.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Hangover Nausea - what are the causes and remedies? (hangovercure.org)
Content: Alcohol is a toxin that directly irritates the stomach lining causing inflammation.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Hangover Nausea - what are the causes and remedies? (hangovercure.org)
Content: Alcohol is a diuretic, which causes us to urinate more and, consequently, expel more electrolytes (essential salts and minerals) than the body needs. This makes us dehydrated and not quite on top form: we may be tired, listless, lacking mental acuity and even dizzy.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Hangover Nausea - what are the causes and remedies? (hangovercure.org)
Content: In response to the irritation and inflammation, the cells lining the stomach produce more acid.


Increased acid production, inflammation of the stomach lining and delayed stomach emptying all go hand in hand to leave you feeling queasy.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Cyber Sickness? Why Computer Screens Can Cause Nausea (lumeseyewear.com)
Content: With motion sickness or cyber sickness, your eyes see moving images and signal to the brain that movement is happening.


When you're focusing on the screen, your brain can suffer from the cognitive dissonance of seeing movement while the rest of your body is relatively still.
---
Document ID: 6
Title: Cyber Sickness? Why Computer Screens Can Cause Nausea (lumeseyewear.com)
Content: As a result, your inner ear and other receptors in your body don't get much other feedback that this movement is taking place - and your central nervous system gets conflicting messages.

question_src: 如果我们品尝的大部分是由气味确定的，为什么有些闻起来有些气味的东西（古龙水，香水，肥皂等）味道不好？ （从/r/r/dimendlikeimfive重新启动/改写）
all_claims: 虽然嗅觉可占风味感知的大部分，但味觉仍依赖口腔味蕾上的受体，只有当甜、咸等特定分子与之结合时才产生愉快信号[4]。
香水、古龙水和肥皂把挥发性芳香分子溶于高浓度乙醇，它们旨在被鼻腔屋顶的嗅觉神经元侦测，闻起来怡人，却几乎不能激活味蕾中负责“甜”“鲜”等正向味道的受体[3]。
若真的入口，乙醇和香料油往往刺激“苦”“酸”受体并产生灼热感，人类进化上将这种化学提示与潜在毒性联系，自动排斥；事实上吞下约30 mL香水中的酒精即可出现中毒症状[1]。
因此嗅觉给出的“好闻”和味觉出于安全而发出的“难吃”在大脑整合后形成了截然不同的体验[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Perfume Poisoning: Symptoms, Dangers, and What to Do (www.healthline.com)
Content: The scented ingredients in perfume are infused into these alcohols as a way of preserving and stabilizing the product’s desired scent. These alcohols are toxic, and may cause symptoms if swallowed in amounts greater than 30 milliliters.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Taste and Smell (www.brainfacts.org)
Content: Taste and smell are separate senses with their own receptor organs, yet they are intimately entwined. Tastants, chemicals in foods, are detected by taste buds, which consist of special sensory cells. When stimulated, these cells send signals to specific areas of the brain, which make us conscious of the perception of taste. Similarly, specialized cells in the nose pick up odorants, airborne odor molecules. Odorants stimulate receptor proteins found on hairlike cilia at the tips of the sensory cells, a process that initiates a neural response. Ultimately, messages about taste and smell converge, allowing us to detect the flavors of food.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Taste and Smell (www.brainfacts.org)
Content: Airborne odor molecules, called odorants, are detected by specialized sensory neurons located in a small patch of mucus membrane lining the roof of the nose. Axons of these sensory cells pass through perforations in the overlying bone and enter two elongated olfactory bulbs lying against the underside of the frontal lobe of the brain.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Taste and Smell | Boundless Biology (courses.lumenlearning.com)
Content: The senses of smell and taste combine at the back of the throat. When you taste something before you smell it, the smell lingers internally up to the nose causing you to smell it. Both smell and taste use chemoreceptors, which essentially means they are both sensing the chemical environment. This chemoreception in regards to taste, occurs via the presence of specialized taste receptors within the mouth that are referred to as taste cells and are bundled together to form taste buds. These taste buds, located in papillae which are found across the tongue, are specific for the five modalities: salt, sweet, sour, bitter and umami. These receptors are activated when their specific stimulus (i.e. sweet or salt molecules) is present and signals to the brain.
---

claim: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”；它本质上是一个矢量量。
question_src: 什么是“磁矩”
all_claims: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”[1]；它本质上是一个矢量量[1]。
磁矩与外磁场相互作用时会产生取向扭矩，这一特性解释了磁针能自动指向磁场方向[2]。
对于载流圆环，磁矩方向垂直于环面，可用右手定则确定[3]。
在原子层面，多数电子自旋磁矩相互抵消，但若某些自旋未被完全抵消，残余自旋磁矩便叠加形成原子的净磁矩，从而赋予材料宏观磁性[4]。
行星亦可表现出磁偶极矩，例如地球与木星的磁偶极矩相对自转轴倾角约10°，而土星的几乎与自转轴重合[5]。

claim: 美国国债持续增加的核心原因是联邦政府几乎年年支出高于收入，形成经常性赤字，因此债务无论战事如何都会累积。
question_src: 即使美国经济的表现与2007年以来一样出色，而我们没有在战争中继续增加？
all_claims: 美国国债持续增加的核心原因是联邦政府几乎年年支出高于收入，形成经常性赤字，因此债务无论战事如何都会累积[1]。
经济自2007年以来表现强劲仅提高了国家的借款能力：经济规模扩大意味着更大的资本市场和更高的税收潜力，政府可以更轻松地发行新债，使得衡量负担的重点转向债务占国内生产总值的比例，而非债务的绝对金额[2]。
换言之，只要财政政策仍让开支超过收入，即便没有新的大型战争成本，债务总额依旧会上涨；债务的可持续性取决于其与GDP之比是否保持在经济可以支撑的水平。
claims_retained: 美国国债持续增加的核心原因是联邦政府几乎年年支出高于收入，形成经常性赤字，因此债务无论战事如何都会累积[1]。
经济自2007年以来表现强劲仅提高了国家的借款能力：经济规模扩大意味着更大的资本市场和更高的税收潜力，政府可以更轻松地发行新债，使得衡量负担的重点转向债务占国内生产总值的比例，而非债务的绝对金额[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: National Debt (www.investopedia.com)
Content: The national debt level of the United States is a measurement of how much the federal government owes its creditors. Specifically, the national debt is a term referring to the level of federal debt held by the public, as opposed to the debt held by the government itself. Since the U.S. government almost always spends more than it takes in, the national debt continues to rise
---
Document ID: 2
Title: National Debt (www.investopedia.com)
Content: While the debt can be measured in trillions of dollars, it is usually measured as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), the debt-to-GDP ratio. That's because as a country's economy grows, the amount of revenue a government can use to pay its debts grows as well.

In addition, a larger economy generally means the country's capital markets will grow and the government can tap them to issue more debt. This means that a country's ability to pay off debt, and the effect that debt might have on the country's economy, is dependent on how large the debt is as a proportion of the overall economy, not the dollar amount
---

question_src: 为什么肥皂几乎可以从您的手上洗掉任何东西，但不会从您身上洗净香水？
all_claims: 肥皂分子一端亲水、一端亲油，能把附着在手表面的油脂和污垢包围成胶束并随水冲走，因此“几乎”能洗掉任何东西；而香水的主要成分是植物性精油或合成香精油，属于脂溶性物质[2]。
这些油性分子喷洒后会与角质层天然脂质混合，并逐渐渗入这层极薄却致密的屏障[4]；角质层内侧是含水环境，油性分子既难继续深入，也不易被水分子带出，从而被牢牢“卡”在皮肤脂质层中。
洗手时肥皂主要作用于皮肤外表面，难以充分接触并溶解已嵌入角质层的香水分子，所以香味仍可持续数小时甚至更久，而其他表面污染物则被迅速洗净。
claims_retained: 这些油性分子喷洒后会与角质层天然脂质混合，并逐渐渗入这层极薄却致密的屏障[4]；角质层内侧是含水环境，油性分子既难继续深入，也不易被水分子带出，从而被牢牢“卡”在皮肤脂质层中。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How to Make Soap from Scratch (www.healthline.com)
Content: Soap, by definition, is fat or oil mixed with an alkali. The oil is from an animal or plant, while the alkali is a chemical called lye. In bar soapmaking, the lye is sodium hydroxide. Liquid soap requires potassium hydroxide.


When oil and lye are combined and heated, the result is soap. This chemical reaction is called saponification. Without lye, saponification isn’t possible, so lye is necessary to create soap.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How to Make Soap from Scratch (www.healthline.com)
Content: Technically, soap doesn’t need a scent to clean the skin. But if you’d like to add a pleasant smell, you can use essential oils or fragrance oils.


Essential oils are mostly plant-based and can be combined to create custom aromas. Fragrance oils are synthetic. When selecting fragrance oils, look for skin-safe options.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Will my skin soak up the calories in skin cream? (www.thenakedscientists.com)
Content: Given that a normal sized person, a grown up person, has a skin surface area of maybe 2 square metres and given that we're about 70% made up of water on the inside, we would lose a lot of water across the skin if it didn't perform efficiently as a protected barrier. It carries out this remarkable feat primarily through a very thin specialised layer, the stratum corneum.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Will my skin soak up the calories in skin cream? (www.thenakedscientists.com)
Content: But where do the oils of the fats go in the end? Well, they mix in with the natural lipids of the stratum corneum and some may well move gradually into the deeper layers of this thin barrier. But once on the other side, they encounter an environment which is very watery. In oily substance, this is not an attractive place and therefore, fat transfer out of the stratum corneum will be very slow and unfavourable.
---
Using the above information, the response is the answer to the query or task: "为什么肥皂几乎可以从您的手上洗掉任何东西，但不会从您身上洗净香水？" in a single sentence.

question_src: 如果您被拉开了怎么办？
all_claims: 被警察示意停车时，先安全靠边并熄火[1]，完全摇下车窗、丢掉口香糖，并把双手放在方向盘上；若在夜间，打开车内灯以便警员看清[1]。
随后保持礼貌，配合一切合法指令[6]，当对方索要资料时，仅须递交驾驶执照、车辆注册和保险证明[2]。
如果警员要求你下车，你无权拒绝[3]。
交谈时可采取反映式倾听，如“嗯”“我理解”，避免做出可能不利的实质性陈述[7]。
警员将每次交通拦停都视作潜在危险，应让其始终看到你的双手、降低警觉[5]；一旦其具备合理怀疑，也可在未获同意的情况下搜车[4]。

question_src: 直到美国，约有100万亿美元的债务是国内拥有的。 eli5我们如何欠自己10万亿美元。
all_claims: 所谓“我们欠自己约10万亿美元”，指的是“政府内债务”：财政部为了把社保、军人退休金等基金收到的盈余现金安全存放并获得利息，会把这些现金换成国债；于是，联邦政府的一只口袋（财政部）欠另一只口袋（各退休基金）钱，看起来债务总额增加了，但债权人仍是美国公民本身[5]。
目前这类内部持有者主要是社会保障信托基金、医疗保险信托基金和军人、文职人员退休基金等，它们合计占国债的很大一块，因此说“美国大多数国债归功于社会保障和养老基金”[1]。
当社保需要兑现福利时，它会把国债还给财政部，由财政部再通过税收或对外发行新债筹钱兑付，因此内部债务虽是“左口袋借右口袋”，但仍是一项必须兑现的真实承诺。

Title: The Real Owner of the US Debt Will Surprise You (www.thebalance.com)
Content: Many people believe that much of U.S. debt is owed to foreign countries like China and Japan. The truth is, most of it is owed to Social Security and pension funds. This means U.S. citizens, through their retirement money, own most of the national debt.

U.S. national debt is the sum of these two federal debt categories:

 * Public debt, held by other countries, the Federal Reserve, mutual funds, and other entities and individuals * Intragovernmental holdings, held by Social Security, Military Retirement Fund, Medicare, and other retirement funds

---
Document ID: 3
Title: The Real Owner of the US Debt Will Surprise You (www.thebalance.com)
Content: The public holds over $21 trillion, or almost 78%, of the national debt. Foreign governments hold about a third of the public debt, while the rest is owned by U.S. banks and investors, the Federal Reserve, state and local governments, mutual funds, pensions funds, insurance companies, and savings bonds.

claim: 释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿。
question_src: 为什么将文件加载到99％的情况下，没有问题，然后悬挂着永远的状态？
all_claims: 文件复制显示 99% 时，数据主体几乎已写完，剩余的 1% 通常包含文件系统元数据更新、缓存刷新和碎片整理等收尾操作；如果目标磁盘空间紧张、碎片度高或存在错误，系统为了保证数据完整性会反复寻址与重写，从而让进度条长时间停留在 99% 看似“永远不动”。
Windows 10 会在后台尝试自动优化磁盘，但当驱动器过度碎片化或可用空间不足时，这一步骤会被拉长或暂停，使复制过程被迫等待。
释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿[1]。
此外，实时杀毒、USB 接口带宽不足或硬盘出现坏道也会使这最后的同步阶段耗时倍增。
简言之，99% 卡顿多半是磁盘端瓶颈而非复制功能故障，通过检查磁盘健康、关闭占用高的后台任务并定期优化驱动器，能显著缩短该阶段耗时并避免“挂着永远”的现象。
claims_retained: 释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿[1]。

claim: 根据目前的物理学理解，人类既没有找到安全“将一个人送入大量时间的方法”，也从未观察到像科幻作品那样来回的时光旅行；霍金甚至以“我们没有被成群的游客入侵未来”来强调此事几乎不可能发生。
question_src: 如果我及时回去几天，然后有人给我的手机打电话会怎样？
all_claims: 根据目前的物理学理解，人类既没有找到安全“将一个人送入大量时间的方法”，也从未观察到像科幻作品那样来回的时光旅行；霍金甚至以“我们没有被成群的游客入侵未来”来强调此事几乎不可能发生[1]。
因此，现实层面上你无法先“回到几天前”再接电话。
不过，若纯作思想实验：你的手机和 SIM 若随你一起穿越到过去，它将脱离原先蜂窝网络的基站时空坐标；当友人在“原来的”时间点拨号时，网络只会在当下寻找该设备，却发现它不在信号覆盖范围，于是呼叫会直接失败或进入语音信箱。
如果你的手机未随身穿越，则它仍留在原时间线，照常响铃，而你身处过去自然听不到。
总之，无论哪种假设，呼叫者都无法在那一刻通过常规移动通信接通你，因为移动网络的时空定位与设备的物理位置不再匹配，而真实世界又缺乏允许信号逆向穿越时间的机制。

Content: Although many people are fascinated by the idea of changing the past or seeing the future before it's due, no person has ever demonstrated the kind of back-and-forth time travel seen in science fiction, or proposed a method of sending a person through significant periods of time that wouldn't destroy them on the way. And, as physicist Stephen Hawking pointed out in his book "Black Holes and Baby Universes" (Bantam, 1994), "The best evidence we have that time travel is not possible, and never will be, is that we have not been invaded by hordes of tourists from the future."

claim: 居民迁徙后，无人维护的建筑风化崩塌；植物在废墟上生长、死亡、腐烂，数百年间逐渐堆出新的土壤层。
question_src: ;古老的文明如何被污垢，沙子等覆盖？
all_claims: 古城并非瞬间沉没，而是在自然作用与人类活动双重影响下逐层被埋。
居民迁徙后，无人维护的建筑风化崩塌；植物在废墟上生长、死亡、腐烂，数百年间逐渐堆出新的土壤层[1]。
尘土与沙粒被风带来覆盖地面，暴雨触发的泥石流和洪水把沉积物倾泻其上；地震和风暴进一步摧毁墙体并改变地形，使碎片更易被沉积物填平[1]。
与此同时，定居点不断输入粮食、木材和砖石，却少有系统清理垃圾和建筑残渣，这些人工堆积使地面缓慢抬高，把早期街道与房屋压入地下，形成典型的“土丘城市”(tell)现象[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How Did Ancient Civilizations Get Buried? (parade.com)
Content: With certain notable exceptions, such as Pompeii, only abandoned fragments of past civilizations were buried by natural forces. People migrated and disseminated, leaving unwanted structures behind. Deserted buildings degraded from a lack of maintenance; plants overtook the space, died and decayed, building layers of soil over the centuries. Dust and debris from neighboring areas blew over the land, rains caused mudslides, storms toppled walls, earthquakes reshaped the local topography over time, and more.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why do we have to dig so deep to uncover ancient ruins? (www.sciencefocus.com)
Content: There is a survivorship bias at work here: buildings and monuments left exposed on the surface don’t last very long. Humans steal the best bits to reuse in other buildings, and erosion wears everything else to dust. So the only ancient ruins we find are the ones that were buried.


But they got buried in the first place because the ground level of ancient cities tended to steadily rise. Settlements constantly imported food and building materials for the population, but getting rid of waste and rubbish was a much lower priority
---

claim: 当我们目睹一只蚂蚁或小虫爬行时，大脑中的感觉与视觉系统会迅速联想并激活“皮肤有东西爬”的记忆模板；若随后皮肤受压、出汗或神经末梢自发放电，就可能出现“有虫在身上爬”的错觉，这种现象医学上称为形成（formication），属于感觉异常和触觉幻觉。
question_src: 是什么使我们想象看到蚂蚁/昆虫在看到一只蚂蚁/昆虫爬行？
all_claims: 当我们目睹一只蚂蚁或小虫爬行时，大脑中的感觉与视觉系统会迅速联想并激活“皮肤有东西爬”的记忆模板；若随后皮肤受压、出汗或神经末梢自发放电，就可能出现“有虫在身上爬”的错觉，这种现象医学上称为形成（formication），属于感觉异常和触觉幻觉[2]。
形成常见于焦虑、激素变化（如更年期）、神经系统疾病（帕金森病、糖尿病神经病）或酒精、药物戒断等情境，此时外部并无真正的昆虫，但大脑错误地解释了来自皮肤或神经的微弱刺激[2]。
视觉提示（看到蚂蚁）与内部不适信号结合，放大了这种错觉，使人“想象”自己也被蚂蚁爬过，从而出现观察—联想—体感的连锁反应[1]。
claims_retained: 当我们目睹一只蚂蚁或小虫爬行时，大脑中的感觉与视觉系统会迅速联想并激活“皮肤有东西爬”的记忆模板；若随后皮肤受压、出汗或神经末梢自发放电，就可能出现“有虫在身上爬”的错觉，这种现象医学上称为形成（formication），属于感觉异常和触觉幻觉[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Feeling of Something Crawling on Head | 3 Formication Causes | Buoy (www.buoyhealth.com)
Content: Formication is the medical term for a sensation of something (usually small insects) crawling on or under the skin. Often formication is associated with no obvious physical cause or external trigger. It is a fairly common occurrence many people can remember a time where they swatted or scratched at such a sensation only to find no bug, insect or bite in sight.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Formication: Anxiety, Menopause, Treatment, Causes, at Night (www.healthline.com)
Content: Formication is the feeling of insects crawling across or underneath your skin. The name comes from the Latin word “formica,”which means ant.


Formication is known as a type of paresthesia. Paresthesia happen when you feel sensations on your skin that don’t have a physical cause. Paresthesia can take many forms. These can include burning, tingling, or numbness. With formication, you might also describe the “crawling” sensation as feeling like “pins and needles.” Formication is also called a tactile hallucination. This means that you’re feeling a sensation that has no physical cause.


Formication can be a symptom of several conditions. These conditions include fibromyalgia and Parkinson’s disease. Withdrawal from alcohol or drug use can also trigger formication.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Formication (www.psychologytoday.com)
Content: Formication is a specific form of the general set of abnormal skin sensations known as paresthesias and tactile hallucinations. It is associated with several disorders: a physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse, diabetic neuropathy, diseases of the spinal cord and peripheral nerves, and extreme alcohol withdrawal with delirium tremens.


This illusion or hallucination that ants or other insects are creeping on or under the skin is a common side effect of large-scale use of cocaine, amphetamines ("amphetamites"), or crystal meth (also known by street names such as "ice," "glass," "chalk," "crank," "meth mites," or "coke bugs.")
---

question_src: Sigma键和PI键有什么区别？
all_claims: Sigma键由两个原子轨道头对头的线性（同轴）重叠形成，而Pi键则由轨道平行的侧向重叠形成[1]；在Pi键中，电子云位于连接原子核的轴的上下两侧，而Sigma键电子密度集中在核连线上[1]。
由于重叠程度更大，Sigma键比Pi键强[2]。
Sigma键可在s与p轨道之间形成，而Pi键主要出现在p或d轨道之间[2]。
原子间的单键必为Sigma键；当存在双键或三键时，除第一键为Sigma键外，其余均为Pi键[2]。
Pi键的出现导致分子不饱和[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Difference Between Sigma and Pi bond - Chemical Bonds (byjus.com)
Content: Sigma bond is a chemical bond formed by the linear or co-axial overlapping of the atomic orbitals of two atoms. A pi bond is a type of covalent bond that exists between atoms where the electrons are on top and bottom of the axis connecting the nuclei of the joined atoms. It is formed by the parallel or lateral overlapping of the atomic orbitals.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Difference Between Sigma and pi Bonds | Compare the Difference Between Similar Terms (www.differencebetween.com)
Content: • Sigma bonds are formed by head to head overlapping of orbitals, whereas pi bonds are formed by the lateral overlapping.


• Sigma bonds are stronger than pi bonds.


• Sigma bonds can be formed between both s and p orbitals whereas pi bonds are mostly formed between p and d orbitals. 


• The single covalent bonds between atoms are sigma bonds. When there are multiple bonds between atoms, pi bonds can be seen.


• pi bonds result in unsaturated molecules.


• Sigma bonds allow free rotation of atoms whereas pi bonds restrict the free rotation.
---

Title: Difference Between Sigma and Pi bond - Chemical Bonds (byjus.com)
Content: Sigma bond is a chemical bond formed by the linear or co-axial overlapping of the atomic orbitals of two atoms. A pi bond is a type of covalent bond that exists between atoms where the electrons are on top and bottom of the axis connecting the nuclei of the joined atoms. It is formed by the parallel or lateral overlapping of the atomic orbitals.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Difference Between Sigma and pi Bonds | Compare the Difference Between Similar Terms (www.differencebetween.com)
Content: • Sigma bonds are formed by head to head overlapping of orbitals, whereas pi bonds are formed by the lateral overlapping.


• Sigma bonds are stronger than pi bonds.


• Sigma bonds can be formed between both s and p orbitals whereas pi bonds are mostly formed between p and d orbitals. 


• The single covalent bonds between atoms are sigma bonds. When there are multiple bonds between atoms, pi bonds can be seen.


• pi bonds result in unsaturated molecules.


• Sigma bonds allow free rotation of atoms whereas pi bonds restrict the free rotation.
---

claim: 当你在首次公开募股（IPO）阶段买入一家公司的股票时，支付的资金直接流入公司账上，成为其扩张或日常运营的资本来源；而在IPO之后的大多数交易中，你通过交易所向其他投资者购买同一股票，资金只是从你的口袋转到卖出者口袋，交易所负责撮合并记录这种供求。
question_src: 钱如何从我的口袋里，通过股票市场，以支持我从股票购买的业务？
all_claims: 当你在首次公开募股（IPO）阶段买入一家公司的股票时，支付的资金直接流入公司账上，成为其扩张或日常运营的资本来源[2]；而在IPO之后的大多数交易中，你通过交易所向其他投资者购买同一股票，资金只是从你的口袋转到卖出者口袋，交易所负责撮合并记录这种供求[2]。
尽管此时公司并未收到现金，但活跃且上涨的股价可提升其市值与信誉，使其未来再度发行新股或其他证券时以更低成本筹资，从而间接得到支持[3]。
无论交易发生在哪个阶段，你获得的都是公司所有权份额，拥有投票权及对公司未来利润和剩余资产的索取权，并可通过股价上涨或分红获取回报[1]。
claims_retained: 当你在首次公开募股（IPO）阶段买入一家公司的股票时，支付的资金直接流入公司账上，成为其扩张或日常运营的资本来源[2]；而在IPO之后的大多数交易中，你通过交易所向其他投资者购买同一股票，资金只是从你的口袋转到卖出者口袋，交易所负责撮合并记录这种供求[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: A Breakdown on How the Stock Market Works (www.investopedia.com)
Content: * Stocks, or shares of a company, represent ownership equity in the firm, which give shareholders voting rights as well as a residual claim on corporate earnings in the form of capital gains and dividends.
* Stock markets are where individual and institutional investors come together to buy and sell shares in a public venue. Nowadays these exchanges exist as electronic marketplaces.
* Share prices are set by supply and demand in the market as buyers and sellers place orders. Order flow and bid-ask spreads are often maintained by specialists or market makers to ensure an orderly and fair market.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: What Is the Stock Market and How Does It Work? - NerdWallet (www.nerdwallet.com)
Content: The stock market works through a network of exchanges — you may have heard of the New York Stock Exchange or the Nasdaq. Companies list shares of their stock on an exchange through a process called an initial public offering, or IPO. Investors purchase those shares, which allows the company to raise money to grow its business. Investors can then buy and sell these stocks among themselves, and the exchange tracks the supply and demand of each listed stock.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How Does The Stock Market Work? (www.forbes.com)
Content: The stock market is a constellation of exchanges where securities like stocks and bonds are bought and sold. In the United States, “the stock market” and “Wall Street” can refer to the entire world of securities trading—including stock exchanges where the shares of public companies are listed for sale and markets where other securities are traded.


The stock market helps companies raise money to fund operations by selling shares of stock, and it creates and sustains wealth for individual investors.
---

claim: 石油和天然气钻探期间进行的水力压裂会产生大量含盐废水，运营方常将其以高压连续泵入数千米深的处置井，此举迅速向地下断层注入流体，抬升孔隙压力、削弱摩擦力，使断层更易滑动，从而诱发地震。
question_src: 为什么石油和天然气钻机可能导致地震并跌落？
all_claims: 石油和天然气钻探期间进行的水力压裂会产生大量含盐废水，运营方常将其以高压连续泵入数千米深的处置井，此举迅速向地下断层注入流体，抬升孔隙压力、削弱摩擦力，使断层更易滑动，从而诱发地震[1]。
在美国俄克拉荷马州，自2008 年起地震次数激增，与少数高注入量废水井有关；研究显示仅 4 口井就占到该州 20% 的地震触发源，且注入液体可在 30 km 之外激活断层，可见影响范围之广[2]。
风险大小与注入体积和速率呈正相关，年注入量往往达到数亿加仑[1]。
因此，减少废水总量、降低注入速率、改用回收或浅层处理、及时停井并加强微震监测，被视为降低诱发地震及随之可能出现的局部地面下沉风险的有效做法。
claims_retained: 石油和天然气钻探期间进行的水力压裂会产生大量含盐废水，运营方常将其以高压连续泵入数千米深的处置井，此举迅速向地下断层注入流体，抬升孔隙压力、削弱摩擦力，使断层更易滑动，从而诱发地震[1]。
在美国俄克拉荷马州，自2008 年起地震次数激增，与少数高注入量废水井有关；研究显示仅 4 口井就占到该州 20% 的地震触发源，且注入液体可在 30 km 之外激活断层，可见影响范围之广[2]。
风险大小与注入体积和速率呈正相关，年注入量往往达到数亿加仑[1]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Is Oil And Gas Activity Causing Earthquakes? And Can We Reduce The Risk? (www.iflscience.com)
Content: Studies including two reports issued in April, indicate that human activities, including activities related to oil and gas extraction, are beginning to play a significant role in triggering earthquakes in the central US.


Extracting oil and gas from shale rock involves cracking, or fracturing, a layer of underground rock with a high-pressure mix of water, sand, and chemicals. As the oil and gas are released, those injection fluids and briny water also come up. That wastewater is later disposed of in what are called injection wells, or sometimes disposal wells.


It is important to note that it is not the fracking process itself that usually causes these earthquakes; it is the rapid injection of fluid during wastewater disposal that sometimes pumps hundreds of millions of gallons of brine deep into the earth each year.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Sharp increase in central Oklahoma seismicity since 2008 induced by massive wastewater injection (www.sciencemag.org)
Content: The number of earthquakes is increasing in regions with active unconventional oil and gas wells, where water pumped at high pressure breaks open rock containing natural gas, leaving behind wastewater in need of disposing. Keranen et al. show that the steep rise in earthquakes in Oklahoma, USA, is likely caused by fluid migration from wastewater disposal wells. Twenty percent of the earthquakes in the central United States could be attributed to just four of the wells. Injected fluids in high-volume wells triggered earthquakes over 30 km away.


Science, this issue p. 448
---

claim: 法律上虽然规定被告在判决前享有“无罪推定”，但现金保释制度使贫困被告无法缴纳高额保释金而被迫羁押，实际削弱了这一原则。
question_src: 如果您仍然必须在审判之前花时间在监狱中，您在被证明有罪之前如何无辜？
all_claims: 法律上虽然规定被告在判决前享有“无罪推定”，但现金保释制度使贫困被告无法缴纳高额保释金而被迫羁押，实际削弱了这一原则[3]。
佩瑟因62.5万美元保释金无力支付，被关押了整整半年，直到陪审团确认他“在所有方面都不有罪”才获释[1]。
数据表明，像他这样在审前被羁押的被告更可能认罪或被判处更长刑期，因为身处监狱无法有效与检察官讨价还价，急于“脱身”[3]。
对于轻罪，等待开庭的数日或数周往往已等同潜在刑期，使人即便无辜也倾向接受认罪协议[3]。
因此，当贫困导致无法获得自由，“先坐牢再辩护”的现实便让“无罪推定”成为纸面承诺，引发“尚未定罪却已失去自由”的质疑。

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)
Content: Peyser's bail was set at $625,000, based on the schedule for his alleged crimes. The attempted murder charge was later dropped, but the bail didn't change. If Peyser wanted to fight these charges from outside of a jail cell, he needed to either cough up cash or pay a bail bondsman a portion of the cost (typically 10 percent) to front the money for him.

Peyser did not have that much. He qualified for representation by a public defender because he was considered indigent. He and his defense attorneys tried to get multiple judges to reduce his bail, pointing out his stellar record and the possibility of losing both his taxi medallion and his rent-controlled apartment. He had turned the gun over to police and didn't want it back. He promised to stay away from the neighbors.

No dice. He would spend half a year in jail until his case was heard in October, at which point the jury watched the security footage of what happened, deliberated, and found him not guilty on all counts. "It looked like an old man doing something stupid," says one juror, speaking to Reason on condition of anonymity. The charges—which required proof of intent—didn't match what they
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)
Content: Even though Peyser was ultimately exonerated, the whole incident imposed a steep cost. He had to give up his taxi medallion and is no longer working. His landlord also started proceedings to evict him, though he was eventually able to convince the landlord to let him stay.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)
Content: When defendants are stuck in jail while awaiting trial, data indicate they're more likely to plead guilty or be found guilty of crimes. They're also likely to be given longer prison sentences. This is partly a result of their not being in a position to bargain with prosecutors, because they're stuck behind bars and desperate to move things along.

For low-level crimes, all that time spent in pretrial detention can be equivalent to the length of the sentence they'll get if they're found guilty anyway. A poor defendant who can't afford bail may spend days, even weeks, in jail waiting to see a judge for a crime where prison time might not even be required. At that point, it's hard to justify spending time or money fighting the charge, even if backing down leaves an innocent person with a criminal record.

"Everybody who works in the system knows that the assembly-line cash bail system coerces guilty pleas," says Civil Rights Corps founder and executive director Alec Karakatsanis. Because American courts don't have the manpower to prosecute and try every person who gets arrested, he argues, "the system needs a way to coerce them into pleading guilty. The most effective way is to keep them in jail."
---

Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)

Document ID: 3
Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)
Content: When defendants are stuck in jail while awaiting trial, data indicate they're more likely to plead guilty or be found guilty of crimes. They're also likely to be given longer prison sentences. This is partly a result of their not being in a position to bargain with prosecutors, because they're stuck behind bars and desperate to move things along.

For low-level crimes, all that time spent in pretrial detention can be equivalent to the length of the sentence they'll get if they're found guilty anyway. A poor defendant who can't afford bail may spend days, even weeks, in jail waiting to see a judge for a crime where prison time might not even be required. At that point, it's hard to justify spending time or money fighting the charge, even if backing down leaves an innocent person with a criminal record.

"Everybody who works in the system knows that the assembly-line cash bail system coerces guilty pleas," says Civil Rights Corps founder and executive director Alec Karakatsanis. Because American courts don't have the manpower to prosecute and try every person who gets arrested, he argues, "the system needs a way to coerce them into pleading guilty. The most effective way is to keep them in jail."
---

claim: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大。
question_src: 为什么我们使用填充空气的轮胎，而不是由实心橡胶制成的轮胎，而不会冒着平坦的风险？
all_claims: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大[1]。
其次，空气近似无重，充气轮胎整体质量显著低于同尺寸的实心橡胶轮胎，较轻的轮胎可减小发动机负荷，使汽车加速更快、油耗更低[1]。
再次，空气能随温度和载荷收缩、膨胀，为胎体提供可变形空间，减少橡胶与轮辋的摩擦磨损，延长寿命[3]。
综合舒适性、能耗与耐用度的优势，充气轮胎的收益远大于偶发爆胎所带来的维护成本，因此至今仍是乘用车的主流选择。
claims_retained: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大[1]。

Title: Why Aren't Tires Made Of Solid Rubber Instead of Inflated Air? (www.autoexpose.org)
Content: However, tires made of solid rubber do not absorb vibrations as well as pneumatic tires. This is because the solid construction of the tires makes the tires have no medium to absorb shocks.

So that the solid rubber tire is not suitable for use in passenger cars that prioritize comfort.

Apart from that, there are other disadvantages. Tires made of solid rubber have a higher weight than pneumatic tires. The higher weight will increase the engine load to run the vehicle.

So that if a solid rubber tire is used in a passenger car, the car accelerates slowly and wastes fuel.

From this, it can be concluded that solid rubber is not suitable for use in vehicles operating on the road.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Readers ask: Why aren't tires solid? (mindrightdetroit.com)
Content: The air in the tires can often absorb impact of a hole or bump because of it’s high suspension capabilities. On airless tires, the suspension would be lower, resulting in a rougher ride. Sure, your tires won’t need to be checked, but your car certainly will. This could cause more harm to your vehicle than good!
---

claim: 发生地震前后，动物被认为依靠比人类更灵敏的感官捕捉到地面轻微振动等早期信号。
question_src: 动物如何感知即将到来的地震？
all_claims: 发生地震前后，动物被认为依靠比人类更灵敏的感官捕捉到地面轻微振动等早期信号[1]。
P波是地震产生的第一波[5]，它们比破坏性的S波先到达地表，许多具有敏锐听觉或触觉的动物能够在S波到来前感知这些较小而快速的振动或低频声波，因而出现突然奔跑、吠叫或集体迁移等异常行为[4]。
另一种理论认为，岩层断裂时释放的电磁变化或气体可改变周围空气的电场，动物通过皮肤、毛发或胡须探测到这种微弱电气信号，提前做出反应[1]。
还有假设指出，大象等社会性动物可能通过长期积累的经验学习，当族长感觉到远处地面的隆隆声时，会迅速带领族群向高处撤离，显示感觉与行为记忆的共同作用[3]。
不过，动物也会因觅食、求偶或躲避捕食者而出现类似行为，给科学验证增加了难度，因此尚无公认的“动物预测地震”机制[2]。

Title: Can Animals Sense Earthquakes? (www.nationalgeographic.com)
Content: One theory is that wild and domestic creatures feel the Earth vibrate before humans. Other ideas suggest they detect electrical changes in the air or gas released from the Earth.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Can Animals Sense Earthquakes? (www.nationalgeographic.com)
Content: "Animals react to so many things—being hungry, defending their territories, mating, predators—so it's hard to have a controlled study to get that advanced warning signal."
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How Animals Sense Earthquakes - Earth in Transition (www.earthintransition.org)
Content: One possibility is that certain animals sense the earthquake itself, even if it’s thousands of miles away. question_src: 是主要的新闻媒体建立了政治偏见还是随着时间的流逝而形成？
all_claims: 从十九世纪起，美国报纸就与特定政党和出版商经济利益紧密相连，显示媒体一开始就带有鲜明政治立场，而非后来才被“主流媒体”蓄意植入[1]。
随后赫斯特与普利策的“黄色新闻”大战为销量与政治议程大肆夸张煽情，偏见因商业竞争与社会运动而进一步演化[2]。
尽管二十世纪出现强调“奥林匹亚式客观性”的职业规范，记者仍难完全摆脱选词、篇幅与赞助商等结构性限制，几乎任何新闻机构都会被指存在某种倾向[3]。
综上，政治偏见并非由现代主要新闻媒体单独“建立”，而是伴随媒体历史、商业模式与社会环境逐步形成并不断变化的长期产物。
claims_retained: 从十九世纪起，美国报纸就与特定政党和出版商经济利益紧密相连，显示媒体一开始就带有鲜明政治立场，而非后来才被“主流媒体”蓄意植入[1]。
随后赫斯特与普利策的“黄色新闻”大战为销量与政治议程大肆夸张煽情，偏见因商业竞争与社会运动而进一步演化[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: A Brief History of Media Bias (www.hoover.org)
Content: The roots of media bias go back to the nineteenth century, and complaints about bias in part reflect a questionable idea about the media’s role and purpose: that newspapers and other dispensers of public information exist to transmit objective, factual information gleaned and communicated by credentialed professionals.


In fact, the notion that reporters should possess Olympian objectivity is relatively recent. In the nineteenth century, most newspapers were explicitly linked to a particular political party and the economic interests of the publisher.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: A Brief History of Media Bias (www.hoover.org)
Content: The tradition of lurid sensationalism, scandal-mongering, and exaggeration put in service to profits and a political agenda continued in the “yellow journalism” famously on display in the circulation war between the Hearst and Pulitzer newspapers in the late nineteenth century. More significantly, that was also when the progressive movement promoted the notion that the proper function of the media was to instruct and shape the opinions of voters too uninformed and irrational to be trusted with making the right choice based on facts alone.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What is Media Bias and Where does It Come from? (with pictures) (www.infobloom.com)
Content: It is almost impossible for any network or journalistic publication not to be accused of some bias. Subtle things like word choice, time limits on programming, and sponsors may all suggest that the organization isn't neutral. Each individual who reports or writes the news also has to work hard to guard against revealing his or her own opinions. These opinions can reveal bias simply through word choice or inflections and tone of voice when delivering news.


[Image: The media is often described as biased.] The media is often described as biased.


One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story. Often, this may be viewed as failing to include the opposite viewpoint, but it would be virtually impossible to include all viewpoints on a particular issue, since people approach issues from more than two directions. For example, those belonging to fringe political parties like the Libertarians or Green Party, often feel their viewpoint is not adequately represented in journalism.


[Image: One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.] One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.


This failure to represent all sides of the story may not be intentional bias, however. News stories may simply not have the time to cover all points of view, and may stick to classic “sides,” such as left and right, in an attempt to curb media bias. The media can still technically be biased since it cannot represent all points of view.
---

More significantly, that was also when the progressive movement promoted the notion that the proper function of the media was to instruct and shape the opinions of voters too uninformed and irrational to be trusted with making the right choice based on facts alone.

Document ID: 3
Title: What is Media Bias and Where does It Come from? (with pictures) (www.infobloom.com)
Content: It is almost impossible for any network or journalistic publication not to be accused of some bias. Subtle things like word choice, time limits on programming, and sponsors may all suggest that the organization isn't neutral. Each individual who reports or writes the news also has to work hard to guard against revealing his or her own opinions. These opinions can reveal bias simply through word choice or inflections and tone of voice when delivering news.


[Image: The media is often described as biased.] The media is often described as biased.


One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story. Often, this may be viewed as failing to include the opposite viewpoint, but it would be virtually impossible to include all viewpoints on a particular issue, since people approach issues from more than two directions. For example, those belonging to fringe political parties like the Libertarians or Green Party, often feel their viewpoint is not adequately represented in journalism.


[Image: One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.] One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.


This failure to represent all sides of the story may not be intentional bias, however. News stories may simply not have the time to cover all points of view, and may stick to classic “sides,” such as left and right, in an attempt to curb media bias. The media can still technically be biased since it cannot represent all points of view.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Understanding the Monty Hall Problem – BetterExplained (betterexplained.com)
Content: The Monty Hall problem is a counter-intuitive statistics puzzle:


* There are 3 doors, behind which are two goats and a car.
* You pick a door (call it door A). You’re hoping for the car of course.
* Monty Hall, the game show host, examines the other doors (B & C) and opens one with a goat. (If both doors have goats, he picks randomly.)


Here’s the game: Do you stick with door A (original guess) or switch to the unopened door? Does it matter?


Surprisingly, the odds aren’t 50-50. If you switch doors you’ll win 2/3 of the time!


Today let’s get an intuition for why a simple game could be so baffling. The game is really about re-evaluating your decisions as new information emerges.


## Play the game


You’re probably muttering that two doors mean it’s a 50-50 chance. Ok bub, let’s play the game:


Try playing the game 50 times, using a “pick and hold” strategy. Just pick door 1 (or 2, or 3) and keep clicking. Click click click. Look at your percent win rate. You’ll see it settle around 1/3.


Now reset and play it 20 times, using a “pick and switch” approach. Pick a door, Monty reveals a goat (grey door), and you switch to the other. Look at your win rate. Is it above 50% Is it closer to 60%? To 66%?


There’s a chance the stay-and-hold strategy does decent on a small number of trials (under 20 or so). If you had a coin, how many flips would you need to convince yourself it was fair? You might get 2 heads in a row and think it was rigged. Just play the game a few dozen times to even it out and reduce the noise.


## Understanding Why Switching Works


That’s the hard (but convincing) way of realizing switching works. Here’s an easier way:


If I pick a door and hold, I have a 1/3 chance of winning.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Understanding the Monty Hall Problem – BetterExplained (betterexplained.com)
Content: If I pick a door and hold, I have a 1/3 chance of winning.


My first guess is 1 in 3 — there are 3 random options, right?


If I rigidly stick with my first choice no matter what, I can’t improve my chances. Monty could add 50 doors, blow the other ones up, do a voodoo rain dance — it doesn’t matter. The best I can do with my original choice is 1 in 3. The other door must have the rest of the chances, or 2/3.


The explanation may make sense, but doesn’t explain why the odds “get better” on the other side. (Several readers have left their own explanations in the comments — try them out if the 1/3 stay vs 2/3 switch doesn’t click).
---

question_src: 电力生产期间电子的流量
all_claims: 在电力生产期间，带负电的电子会从其原子外层获得足够能量后脱离束缚，跳跃到相邻原子的外层轨道，这一“接力”式迁移在导体内部形成了连续有序的电子流动[1]；当这种迁移过程在发电装置（如发电机线圈）中被持续驱动时，就产生了我们称为电流的宏观现象[2]。
电流大小取决于单位时间内通过导体截面的电子总量，若保持电子流动的方向和速率稳定，则可输出稳定的电力[1]。
在国际单位制中，1 安培电流对应每秒约6.24 × 10¹⁸个电子穿过导体截面，这说明哪怕极短时间内的微观电子运动，也能累积成可观的能量传输。

Content: An atom is the smallest constituent unit of an element that can exist, but within each atom, there are three particles. The three particles include electrons, protons, and neutrons.

The ability of an electron to disassociate itself from one atom and move to the adjacent atom is what makes it the most vital particle when it comes to electricity.


This movement of electrons from one atom to another is what creates an electric current. A consistent flow of electrons within a circuit determines the current in a wire. See how to calculate potential energy to understand electrons and energy.

question_src: 如何发生进化以及第一个生物如何产生
all_claims: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量[1]。
米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分[2]。
这些有机分子经过聚合和自我复制的化学演化，形成最初的原核微生物。
至少24亿年前，部分微生物进化出光合作用，成为蓝细菌，释放氧气，引发大气含氧量急升并改变生态格局[3]。
随后，某些微生物进入他者体内形成互惠共生，演变出线粒体及被膜包裹的细胞核，标志着具有专门细胞器的真核细胞诞生[4]。
真核细胞继续通过分工协作集结为多细胞体，最终在约8亿年前出现最早的动物，开启生物多样化[4]。
化学演化→单细胞→共生复杂化→多细胞的连续过程展示了进化如何发生及最初生命的产生机制。
claims_retained: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量[1]。
米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分[2]。
至少24亿年前，部分微生物进化出光合作用，成为蓝细菌，释放氧气，引发大气含氧量急升并改变生态格局[3]。
随后，某些微生物进入他者体内形成互惠共生，演变出线粒体及被膜包裹的细胞核，标志着具有专门细胞器的真核细胞诞生[4]。
真核细胞继续通过分工协作集结为多细胞体，最终在约8亿年前出现最早的动物，开启生物多样化[4]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: The secret of how life on Earth began (www.bbc.com)
Content: in 1952, Miller began the most famous experiment on the origin of life ever attempted.

The set-up was simple. Miller connected a series of glass flasks and circulated four chemicals that he suspected were present on the early Earth: boiling water, hydrogen gas, ammonia and methane. He subjected the gases to repeated electric shocks, to simulate the lightning strikes that would have been a common occurrence on Earth so long ago
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The secret of how life on Earth began (www.bbc.com)
Content: Miller found that "the water in the flask became noticeably pink after the first day, and by the end of the week the solution was deep red and turbid". Clearly, a mix of chemicals had formed.

When Miller analysed the mixture he found that it contained two amino acids: glycine and alanine. Amino acids are often described as the building blocks of life. They are used to form the proteins that control most biochemical processes in our bodies. Miller had made two of life's most important components, from scratch
---
Document ID: 3
Title: History of Life on Earth (naturalhistory.si.edu)
Content: When cyanobacteria evolved at least 2.4 billion years ago, they set the stage for a remarkable transformation. They became Earth’s first photo-synthesizers, making food using water and the Sun’s energy, and releasing oxygen as a result. This catalyzed a sudden, dramatic rise in oxygen, making the environment less hospitable for other microbes that could not tolerate oxygen
---
Document ID: 4
Title: History of Life on Earth (naturalhistory.si.edu)
Content: While they can process lots of chemicals, microbes did not have the specialized cells that are needed for complex bodies. Animal bodies have various cells –skin, blood, bone – which contain organelles, each doing a distinct job. Microbes are just single cells with no organelles and no nuclei to package their DNA.

Something revolutionary happened as microbes began living inside other microbes, functioning as organelles for them. Mitochondria, the organelles that process food into energy, evolved from these mutually beneficial relationships. Also, for the first time, DNA became packaged in nuclei. The new complex cells (“eukaryotic cells”) boasted specialized parts playing specialized roles that supported the whole cell.

Cells also began living together, probably because certain benefits could be obtained. Groups of cells might be able to feed more efficiently or gain protection from simply being bigger. Living collectively, cells began to support the needs of the group by each cell doing a specific job. Some cells were tasked with making junctions to hold the group together, while other cells made digestive enzymes that could break down food.

## The First Animals

These clusters of specialized, cooperating cells eventually became the first animals, which DNA evidence suggests evolved around 800 million years ago
---
Using the above information, the response is the answer to the query or task: "如何发生进化以及第一个生物如何产生" in a single sentence.
You MUST cite the most relevant document by including only its Source ID in brackets at the end of the sentence (e.g., [Source ID]).
Do NOT include any additional words inside or outside the brackets.
Please output ONLY the number of the Source ID that is most relevant to the sentence.

Response: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量。 [

claim: 米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分。
question_src: 如何发生进化以及第一个生物如何产生
all_claims: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量[1]。
米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分[2]。
这些有机分子经过聚合和自我复制的化学演化，形成最初的原核微生物。
至少24亿年前，部分微生物进化出光合作用，成为蓝细菌，释放氧气，引发大气含氧量急升并改变生态格局[3]。
随后，某些微生物进入他者体内形成互惠共生，演变出线粒体及被膜包裹的细胞核，标志着具有专门细胞器的真核细胞诞生[4]。
真核细胞继续通过分工协作集结为多细胞体，最终在约8亿年前出现最早的动物，开启生物多样化[4]。
化学演化→单细胞→共生复杂化→多细胞的连续过程展示了进化如何发生及最初生命的产生机制。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Second (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: Although the historical definition of the unit was based on this division of the Earth's rotation cycle, the formal definition in the International System of Units (SI) is a much steadier timekeeper:

> The second is defined as being equal to the time duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the fundamental unperturbed ground-state of the caesium-133 atom
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Standard Meter (surveyhistory.org)
Content: The French originated the meter in the 1790s as one/ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the north pole along a meridian through Paris. It is realistically represented by the distance between two marks on an iron bar kept in Paris. The International Bureau of Weights and Measures, created in 1875, upgraded the bar to one made of 90 percent platinum/10 percent iridium alloy.

In 1960 the meter was redefined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange-red light, in a vacuum, produced by burning the element krypton (Kr-86). More recently (1984), the Geneva Conference on Weights and Measures has defined the meter as the distance light travels, in a vacuum, in 1/299,792,458 seconds with time measured by a cesium-133 atomic clock which emits pulses of radiation at very rapid, regular intervals
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Gram (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The gram (alternative spelling: gramme;[1] SI unit symbol: g) is a metric system unit of mass.

Originally defined as "the absolute weight of a volume of pure water equal to the cube of the hundredth part of a metre [1 cm^3], and at the temperature of melting ice"[2] (later at 4 °C, the temperature of maximum density of water). However, in a reversal of reference and defined units, a gram is now defined as one thousandth of the SI base unit, the kilogram, or 1×10−3 kg, which itself is defined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, not in terms of grams, but by taking the fixed numerical value of the Planck constant h to be 6.626 070 15×10−34 kg⋅m^2⋅s−1
---

claim: 当你挠狗的腹部或身体某些“敏感点”时，它常常会突然抬起后腿快速颤动，看起来像在“握手”，这是一种被称为“刮擦反射”的无意识动作。
question_src: 当您刮擦某些部分时，为什么狗会握手？
all_claims: 当你挠狗的腹部或身体某些“敏感点”时，它常常会突然抬起后腿快速颤动，看起来像在“握手”，这是一种被称为“刮擦反射”的无意识动作[1]。
当皮肤上的感觉神经受到刺激时，信号直接传到脊髓并立即激活控制腿部肌肉的运动神经元，使狗自动踢腿，以摆脱被认为可能是风、虫子或其他刺激物的触感[1]。
从进化角度看，这一反射帮助狗迅速用后腿驱赶跳蚤等寄生虫，减少叮咬和感染的风险，具有明显的自我保护价值[2]。
该反射不经大脑决策，完全不受狗主观意愿控制，这也解释了狗在发生“握手”时常显得既惊讶又迷惑[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why do dogs shake their legs? (www.animalplanet.com)
Content: Dogs shake or kick their legs when you scratch them because of something known as the scratch reflex. It's a completely involuntary reaction, which explains why your dog may look as puzzled as you do when it starts to happen. When you scratch or tickle your dog's belly, it irritates him, much the same way that the wind or a bug might. It activates nerves under his skin that are connected to his spinal cord and relays a message to his leg muscles to kick in an attempt to get rid of the irritant.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Mystery Behind Leg Kicking When Scratched (dogdiscoveries.com)
Content: The scratch reflex may have an adaptive purpose of ridding the animal from fleas or other dangerous parasites in an area (the flanks) that isn't highly mobile as say, the tail or the dog's front or hind legs.


The scratch reflex therefore may allow the dog to quickly attempt to remove the stimulus by using his rear leg.

Title: Why do dogs shake their legs? (www.animalplanet.com)
Content: Dogs shake or kick their legs when you scratch them because of something known as the scratch reflex. It's a completely involuntary reaction, which explains why your dog may look as puzzled as you do when it starts to happen. When you scratch or tickle your dog's belly, it irritates him, much the same way that the wind or a bug might. It activates nerves under his skin that are connected to his spinal cord and relays a message to his leg muscles to kick in an attempt to get rid of the irritant.

question_src: 当我打哈欠时，为什么我的嘴有时会喷洒唾液？

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why We Accidentally Spray Saliva When We Yawn (brightside.me)
Content: Your mouth has a heap of muscles, and sometimes you can be doing some mouth thing — like talking or eating — and hit just the right combination, and whoosh, there it goes. When you get a yawn attack, you accidentally squeeze the salivary glands under your tongue, forcing the saliva to squirt out in a spray. Luckily, people can’t gleek again until the ducts are refilled.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why We Accidentally Spray Saliva When We Yawn (brightside.me)
Content: Gleeking happens when a large amount of saliva builds up in your mouth below your tongue: for example, if you’ve eaten something sour or bitter. Saliva is secreted by the major salivary glands. If you look in the mirror while raising your tongue, you can see the ducts that deliver saliva from the glands to the mouth.


Gleeking is achieved by compressing these ducts with muscles in the base of the mouth when you move your tongue upward. If your mouth is wide open the stream can be launched several feet.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How come sometimes when you yawn, a spray of water comes from the back of your mouth? (www.answerbag.com)
Content: I t actually comes from under the tongue. Gleeking is the projection of saliva from the submandibular gland on compression by the tongue. In general, gleeking occurs when an accumulation of saliva in the submandibular gland is propelled out in a stream when the gland is compressed by the tongue. The stream of saliva is released in the general direction of the front of the mouth. If the mouth is open the jet may project several feet. Gleeking is more likely when the salivary gland has been recently stimulated, but even a residual amount of saliva in the gland may be released by gleeking. Gleeking may occur spontaneously due to accidental tongue pressure on the sublingual gland while talking, eating, yawning, or cleaning the teeth.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Why does a spray of water come out of mouth when yawning? - Answers (www.answers.com)
Content: The sublingual caruncle is found under your tongue (either side of the frenulum - the small folds going from your tongue and the cavity floor).


This is where two salivary glands, the sublingual and submandibular glands, empty into the oral cavity. That is why saliva will sometimes spray out when you lift your tongue while yawning.
---
